question: Economics deals primarily with the concept of
option: change.
power.
poverty.
scarcity.
answer: scarcity.

question: Scarcity exists when
option: the price of a good rises.
society can meet the wants of every individual.
there is less of a good or resource available than people wish to have.
there is less than an infinite amount of a resource or good.
answer: there is less of a good or resource available than people wish to have.

question: Economics is defined as the study of
option: how society manages its scarce resources.
business.
central planning.
government regulation.
answer: how society manages its scarce resources.

question: A good definition of equity would be
option: efficiency.
eliminating extreme affluence.
fairness.
everyone receiving the same income.
answer: fairness.

question: When government policies are being designed,
option: increasing efficiency usually results in more equity.
there is usually a tradeoff between equity and efficiency.
equity can usually be achieved without an efficiency loss.
equity and efficiency goals are usually independent of each other.
answer: there is usually a tradeoff between equity and efficiency.

question: The opportunity cost of an item is
option: what you give up to get that item.
always equal to the dollar value of the item.
always less than the dollar value of the item.
the number of hours needed to earn the money to buy it.
answer: what you give up to get that item.

question: Ryan spends an hour studying instead of going for a bike ride. The opportunity cost to him of studying is
option: the improvement in his grades from studying for the hour.
the enjoyment and exercise he would have received had he gone for a bike ride.
the difference between the improvement in his grades from studying minus the enjoyment of a bike ride.
zero. Since Ryan chose to study rather than to ride his bike, the value of studying must have been greater than the value of the bike ride.
answer: the enjoyment and exercise he would have received had he gone for a bike ride.

question: A rational decision maker takes an action only if the
option: marginal benefit is greater than the marginal cost.
average benefit is greater than the average cost.
marginal benefit is less than the marginal cost.
marginal benefit is greater than both the average cost and the marginal cost.
answer: marginal benefit is greater than the marginal cost.

question: A marginal change is a
option: long-term trend.
change for the worse.
small incremental adjustment.
large, significant adjustment.
answer: small incremental adjustment.

question: Economists understand that people respond to
option: the wishes of policymakers.
tax breaks, but not tax hikes.
threats more than rewards.
incentives.
answer: incentives.

question: Which is the most accurate statement about trade?
option: Trade can make every nation better off.
Trade makes some nations better off and others worse off.
Trade helps rich nations and hurts poor nations.
Trading for a good can make a nation better off only if the nation cannot produce that good.
answer: Trade can make every nation better off.

question: If Canada is better than the United States at producing hockey sticks, but the United States is better than Canada at producing roller blades, the United States should
option: put a quota on the amount of Canadian hockey sticks imported.
subsidize its hockey stick industry so that it can compete with Canadian hockey sticks.
sell roller blades to Canada, and buy Canadian hockey sticks.
impose a tariff on Canadian hockey sticks in order to protect jobs in the U.S. roller blade industry.
answer: sell roller blades to Canada, and buy Canadian hockey sticks.

question: In a market economy, economic activity is guided by
option: the government.
corporations.
central planners.
prices.
answer: prices.

question: One advantage market economies have over central planning is that market economies
option: solve the problem of scarcity.
are more efficient.
establish government economic control.
provide an equal distribution of goods and services to consumers.
answer: are more efficient.

question: The term market failure refers to
option: an unsuccessful advertising campaign.
a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.
a situation in which competition among firms becomes ruthless.
a firm which is forced out of business because of losses.
answer: a situation in which the market on its own fails to allocate resources efficiently.

question: An externality is the impact of
option: a person’s actions on that person’s well-being.
society’s decisions on the well-being of society.
one person’s actions on the well-being of a bystander.
society’s decisions on the well-being of one person.
answer: one person’s actions on the well-being of a bystander.

question: If a copper refinery does NOT bear the entire cost of the smoke it emits, it will
option: emit too much smoke.
emit lower levels of smoke.
emit an acceptable level of smoke.
eliminate all smoke so as to avoid the entire cost of the smoke.
answer: emit too much smoke.

question: The two best reasons for a government to intervene in a market are to
option: promote equity and to raise revenues.
promote equity and to promote efficiency.
promote efficiency and to raise revenues.
raise revenues and to promote stability.
answer: promote equity and to promote efficiency.

question: Market power refers to the
option: power of the government to regulate a market.
relative importance of a market to the overall economy.
power of a single person (or small group of people) to unduly influence market prices.
ability of a person or group of people to successfully market new products.
answer: power of a single person (or small group of people) to unduly influence market prices.

question: The income of a typical worker in a country is most closely linked to which of the following?
option: population
government policies
labor unions
productivity
answer: productivity

question: Almost all variation in living standards is attributable to differences in countries’
option: population growth rates.
endowments of natural resources.
defense budgets.
productivity.
answer: productivity.

question: Productivity is defined as the
option: amount of goods and services produced from each hour of a worker’s time.
number of workers required to produce a given amount of goods and services.
amount of labor which can be saved by replacing workers with machines.
actual amount of effort workers put into an hour of working time.
answer: amount of goods and services produced from each hour of a worker’s time.

question: Inflation is defined as
option: a period of rising productivity in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.
a period of rising income in the economy.
an increase in the overall level of output in the economy.
answer: an increase in the overall level of prices in the economy.

question: Inflation causes
option: productivity to increase.
the value of money to rise.
the value of money to fall.
the government to lower taxes.
answer: the value of money to fall.

question: Which of the following is the most correct statement about the relationship between inflation and unemployment?
option: In the long run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the long run, reducing inflation is associated with falling unemployment.
In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.
answer: In the short run, reducing inflation is associated with rising unemployment.

question: Scarcity is the result of
option: an unfair distribution of income.
taxes that are too low.
taxes that are too high.
too few resources to satisfy society’s desires.
answer: too few resources to satisfy society’s desires.

question: A good is considered to be scarce in a society when
option: firms could be producing more of the good but have decided not to.
the government places a tax on the good in an attempt to lower the demand for it.
everyone in that society cannot have all they want of the good.
only the richest people in the economy can buy all they want of the good.
answer: everyone in that society cannot have all they want of the good.

question: Economics is the study of
option: the government’s role in society.
how society manages its scarce resources.
how to operate a profitable business.
successful stock market investing.
answer: how society manages its scarce resources.

question: Efficiency is most closely defined by which of the following?
option: absolute fairness
minimum waste
equal distribution
consumer sovereignty
answer: minimum waste

question: Economists use the word equity to describe a situation in which
option: every member of society would have the same income.
benefits of society’s resources are distributed fairly among its members.
society is getting the most it can from its scarce resources.
those in society who have the least will receive the most.
answer: benefits of society’s resources are distributed fairly among its members.

question: When the government implements such programs as welfare assistance and progressive income tax rates, which of the following is likely to occur?
option: Equity is increased and efficiency is increased.
Equity is decreased and efficiency is increased.
Equity is increased and efficiency is decreased.
Equity is decreased and efficiency is decreased.
answer: Equity is increased and efficiency is decreased.

question: Economists use the phrase “There is no such thing as a free lunch,” to illustrate
option: the concept of inflation.
the concept of tradeoffs.
that people aren’t as generous today as they used to be.
that if something looks too good to be true, it probably is.
answer: the concept of tradeoffs.

question: Whatever must be given up to obtain an item is the definition of
option: equity.
an explicit cost.
efficiency.
opportunity cost.
answer: opportunity cost.

question: When economists refer to people making decisions “at the margin” they mean that people
option: make decisions only if those decisions do not impose a cost.
evaluate how easily a decision can be reversed if problems arise.
always calculate the dollar costs for each decision.
compare the costs and benefits of each decision.
answer: compare the costs and benefits of each decision.

question: Which of the following is the best example of a marginal change?
option: Jayson gets a raise at his part-time job and is now paid $6.75 per hour instead of $6.50.
After graduating college, Megan’s income increases from $500 per month to $3,000 per month.
Due to an increase in the crime rates of a local suburb, housing prices in the area fall by 40%.
A hard freeze wipes out half of the orange crop in Florida and the price of orange juice doubles.
answer: Jayson gets a raise at his part-time job and is now paid $6.75 per hour instead of $6.50.

question: When economists say that individuals respond to incentives, they mean that
option: individuals act very quickly when faced with a problem.
individuals respond to positive stimuli, but not to negative stimuli.
if the benefit of an activity increases, people will engage in more of that activity.
once individuals have made a mistake, they will never make the same mistake again.
answer: if the benefit of an activity increases, people will engage in more of that activity.

question: If Japan decides to trade with Bangladesh, we know that
option: Bangladesh will be better off, but trading with a less-developed country will not help Japan.
Bangladesh and Japan will both be better off with trade.
it will not benefit Bangladesh because workers in Japan are more productive.
it will not benefit either country because they are too culturally different.
answer: Bangladesh and Japan will both be better off with trade.

question: Any nation which chooses to engage in trade
option: will only benefit if it trades with countries that produce goods it cannot produce.
cannot benefit if it trades with less-developed countries.
can benefit by trading with any other country.
should first attempt to produce the good itself.
answer: can benefit by trading with any other country.

question: In Adam Smith’s book The Wealth of Nations, the “invisible hand” refers to
option: human kindness.
the free market system.
supernatural beings.
government restrictions.
answer: the free market system.

question: Profit and self-interest guide the decisions of firms and households in a
option: command economy.
traditional economy.
market economy.
all of the above
answer: market economy.

question: When a market, left on its own, fails to allocate resources efficiently, which of the following has occurred?
option: government interference
economic meltdown
monopoly power
market failure
answer: market failure

question: Which of the following would be an example of an externality?
option: A construction company remodels several run-down, vacant homes in a low-income part of town, improving property values.
Teachers at a local high school have pizza delivered every Friday for lunch.
An elderly couple purchases a hot tub to ease their arthritis.
John buys a tractor to mow his newly purchased 5-acre lot.
answer: A construction company remodels several run-down, vacant homes in a low-income part of town, improving property values.

question: Market failure can be caused by
option: market power and supply shocks.
externalities and market power.
government intervention and low consumer demand.
high prices and foreign competition.
answer: externalities and market power.

question: An example of a firm with market power would be a
option: video rental store in Dallas.
farmer in Iowa.
gas station in Tallahassee.
cable TV provider in a Kansas City suburb.
answer: cable TV provider in a Kansas City suburb.

question: The primary determinant of a country’s standard of living is
option: the ability to reduce foreign competition.
its ability to produce goods and services.
the total supply of money in the economy.
the average age of the country’s labor force.
answer: its ability to produce goods and services.

question: Suppose that the average income of a Brazilian is higher than the average income of a Canadian. You might conclude that
option: Canadian firms are faced with stricter government regulations than in Brazil.
total income is divided among fewer workers in Brazil than in Canada since Brazil has a smaller labor force than Canada.
productivity in Brazil is higher than in Canada.
Brazil’s climate allows for longer growing seasons and therefore Brazil can produce large quantities of grain.
answer: productivity in Brazil is higher than in Canada.

question: If the government wanted to enact a policy to increase living standards in the country, it should
option: increase educational opportunities for workers.
make it more difficult to receive unemployment benefits.
strictly enforce all workplace safety regulations.
prohibit any union from restricting membership.
answer: increase educational opportunities for workers.

question: In most cases, the cause of high or persistent inflation is
option: increased government regulations.
higher worker productivity.
growth in the quantity of money.
an increased demand for domestic production.
answer: growth in the quantity of money.

question: In the 1920s, the quantity of money in Germany was increased. As a result
option: unemployment increased.
many people in Germany became rich.
Germany experienced hyperinflation.
Germany was able to repay all its foreign debts.
answer: Germany experienced hyperinflation.

question: According to the Phillips curve
option: there is no tradeoff between inflation and unemployment.
if inflation increases, so does unemployment.
increases in unemployment are associated with a rise in prices.
there is a short-run tradeoff between inflation and unemployment.
answer: there is a short-run tradeoff between inflation and unemployment.

question: The production possibilities frontier is a
option: map which shows the frontier beyond which agriculture is unprofitable.
map which shows areas of the world in which capitalist production is now possible.
graph that shows the various combinations of output that the economy can possibly produce given the available resources and technology.
graph which shows the various combinations of resources that can be used to produce a given level of output.
answer: graph that shows the various combinations of output that the economy can possibly produce given the available resources and technology.

question: Which of the following concepts is NOT illustrated by the production possibilities frontier?
option: efficiency
opportunity cost
equity
tradeoffs
answer: equity

question: The opportunity cost of obtaining more of one good is shown on the production possibilities frontier as the
option: amount of the other good which must be given up.
market price of the additional amount produced.
amount of resources which must be devoted to its production.
number of dollars which must be spent to produce it.
answer: amount of the other good which must be given up.

question: A production possibilities frontier will be linear and not bowed out if
option: no tradeoffs exist.
the tradeoff between the two goods is always at a constant rate.
the unemployment rate is zero.
resources are allocated efficiently.
answer: the tradeoff between the two goods is always at a constant rate.

question: Which of the following would be considered a topic of study in microeconomics?
option: the effect of changes in saving rates on GDP
the impact of minimum-wage laws on employment in the fast-food industry
the impact of monetary policy on the rate of inflation
the effect of tax policy on the rate of economic growth
answer: the impact of minimum-wage laws on employment in the fast-food industry

question: Since economists are unable to obtain economic data by conducting experiments, they generally must
option: do without data.
use whatever data the world gives them.
select a committee of economists to make up data for all economists to use.
ask policymakers to conduct experiments for them.
answer: use whatever data the world gives them.

question: Models
option: allow economists to learn how the economy works.
make the economics profession more difficult than necessary.
based on false assumptions cannot be useful to economists.
must include every possible variable in the economy to be useful to economists.
answer: allow economists to learn how the economy works.

question: When building a model, economists begin by
option: applying for government funding.
conducting controlled experiments in a lab.
making assumptions.
reviewing statistical forecasts.
answer: making assumptions.

question: In a simple two-sector circular-flow diagram,
option: firms are sellers in the resource market and the product market.
households are sellers in the resource market.
firms are buyers in the product market.
households are buyers in both the resource market and the product market.
answer: households are sellers in the resource market.

question: In a simple two-sector circular-flow diagram,
option: spending on goods and services flow from firms to households.
goods and services flow from households to firms.
factors of production flow from firms to households.
income from factors of production flows from firms to households.
answer: income from factors of production flows from firms to households.

question: Which of the following statements about production possibilities frontiers is correct?
option: An economy can produce only on its production possibilities frontier.
More than one point on a production possibilities frontier can be produced if there is an increase in available resources.
An economy can produce at any point on or inside the production possibilities frontier.
An economy can produce at any point outside the production possibilities frontier
answer: An economy can produce at any point on or inside the production possibilities frontier.

question: A point that is on a production possibilities frontier represents a combination of two goods that an economy
option: will never be able to produce.
can produce using all available resources and technology.
can produce using some of its resources and technology.
may be able to produce sometime in the future with additional resources and technology.
answer: can produce using all available resources and technology.

question: The curved shape of the production possibilities frontier can be explained by
option: the fact that some resources are better suited for some types of production than are other resources.
constant cost production.
scarcity.
economic growth.
answer: the fact that some resources are better suited for some types of production than are other resources.

question: Suppose a nation is currently producing at a point inside its production possibilities frontier. We know that
option: the nation is producing beyond its capacity, and inflation will occur.
the nation is producing inefficiently.
the nation is producing efficiently.
there will be a large opportunity cost if the nation tries to increase production.
answer: the nation is producing inefficiently.

question: Anytime an economy’s production possibilities frontier shifts outward, we can say that this economy is experiencing
option: economic growth.
a downturn in the economy.
a more equitable distribution of income within the economy.
an improvement in the allocation of available resources.
answer: economic growth.

question: Macroeconomics is concerned primarily with the
option: way things are produced.
prices of particular goods and services.
behavior of consumers.
study of economy-wide phenomena.
answer: study of economy-wide phenomena.

question: “The government should use any budget surplus to reduce taxes instead of paying down the national debt” is an example of
option: a positive economic statement.
sound fiscal management.
a normative economic statement.
a welfare statement.
answer: a normative economic statement.

question: Economists from the Treasury Department provide
option: the annual Economic Report of the President.
advice on tax policy to the President.
enforcement of the U. S. Antitrust laws.
Congress with the annual budget.
answer: advice on tax policy to the President.

question: The slope of a straight line is calculated by
option: rise divided by run.
run divided by rise.
the average of rise and run.
rise plus run.
answer: rise divided by run.

question: A country’s consumption possibilities frontier can be outside its production possibilities frontier
option: with trade.
by allocating resources differently.
by lowering unemployment in the country.
by producing a greater variety of goods and services.
answer: with trade.

question: If labor in Mexico is less productive than labor in the United States in all areas of production,
option: neither nation can benefit from trade.
Mexico can benefit from trade but the United States cannot.
both nations can benefit from trade.
Mexico will not have a comparative advantage in any good.
answer: both nations can benefit from trade.

question: Comparative advantage is based on
option: capital costs.
labor costs.
dollar price.
opportunity costs.
answer: opportunity costs.

question: Absolute advantage is found by
option: comparing opportunity costs.
calculating the dollar cost of production.
first determining which country has a comparative advantage.
comparing the productivity of one nation to that of another.
answer: comparing the productivity of one nation to that of another.

question: The principle of comparative advantage was developed by
option: Adam Smith.
Harry Truman.
David Ricardo.
John Maynard Keynes.
answer: David Ricardo.

question: Economists generally support
option: government management of trade.
free international trade.
trade restrictions.
export subsidies.
answer: free international trade.

question: Karl Malone (1997 NBA MVP) is a better basketball player and truck driver than Gregory Mankiw (the author of your economics text). Which of the following is true?
option: Karl Malone and Gregory Mankiw may benefit from trade.
Karl Malone would be better off playing basketball and driving his own truck.
Karl Malone will probably have a comparative advantage in both goods.
Karl Malone will have a lower opportunity cost of playing basketball and truck driving than will Gregory Mankiw.
answer: Karl Malone and Gregory Mankiw may benefit from trade.

question: Exports are
option: a limit placed on the quantity of goods brought into a country.
goods produced domestically and sold abroad.
usually a country’s least desirable product.
goods produced abroad and sold domestically.
answer: goods produced domestically and sold abroad.

question: The United States could benefit by
option: promoting imports and restricting exports.
restricting imports and promoting exports.
restricting both imports and exports.
not restricting trade.
answer: not restricting trade.

question: The gains from trade are
option: higher from trade between a rich nation and a poor nation.
a result of more efficient resource allocation.
based on different wage rates between nations.
based on the principle of absolute advantage.
answer: a result of more efficient resource allocation.

question: If a country chooses not to trade, then that country
option: will be better off.
is outside its own production possibilities frontier.
will have a production possibilities frontier equal to its consumption possibilities frontier.
will be able to produce and consume a greater variety of goods and services.
answer: will have a production possibilities frontier equal to its consumption possibilities frontier.

question: Which of the following statements about trade is NOT correct?
option: Trade allows for specialization.
Trade improves a country’s standard of living.
Trade is based on absolute advantage.
Trade is based on which country experiences lower opportunity cost to produce.
answer: Trade is based on absolute advantage.

question: In one hour Matt can debug one computer program or type ten pages of a report. Matt’s opportunity cost of debugging a computer program is
option: one page of a report.
ten pages of a report.
1/10 of a page of a report.
one hour of his time.
answer: ten pages of a report.

question: If Shawn can produce donuts at a lower opportunity cost than Sue, then
option: Shawn has a comparative advantage in the production of donuts.
Sue has a comparative advantage in the production of donuts.
Shawn should be retrained to produce a different product.
it is obvious that Shawn is capable of producing more donuts than Sue.
answer: Shawn has a comparative advantage in the production of donuts.

question: Gains from trade occur when trade is based on
option: the amount of labor resources the two countries have.
the rate of inflation in the two countries.
absolute advantage.
comparative advantage.
answer: comparative advantage.

question: Which of the following is true when countries specialize according to their comparative advantage?
option: It is possible to increase world output of all goods.
It is possible to increase world output of some goods only by reducing the output of others.
One country is likely to gain from trade while others lose.
All countries will lose from trade.
answer: It is possible to increase world output of all goods.

question: A good that is produced abroad and sold domestically is called
option: a quota.
a tariff.
an import.
an export.
answer: an import.

question: A tax placed on imported goods is called
option: a quota.
a tariff.
an import.
an export.
answer: a tariff.

question: David Ricardo
option: believed that barriers to trade, such as tariffs and quotas, were necessary to promote a country’s economic growth.
argued in favor of Britain following a free-trade policy.
was the founder of modern economics.
wrote Why Nations Trade.
answer: argued in favor of Britain following a free-trade policy.

question: Trade can make everybody better off because it
option: increases cooperation among nations.
increases labor costs of production.
requires some workers in an economy to be retrained.
allows people to specialize according to comparative advantage.
answer: allows people to specialize according to comparative advantage.

question: Assume that Hungary has a comparative advantage in wheat and Germany has a comparative advantage in cars. If these two countries specialize and trade according to their comparative advantage
option: Hungary will specialize in and export wheat.
some individuals in each country will be hurt.
more of each good can be consumed in both countries.
All of the above are correct.
answer: All of the above are correct.

question: Assume that Hungary has a comparative advantage in wheat and Germany has a comparative advantage in cars. If these two countries specialize and trade according to their comparative advantage
option: all individuals in both countries will benefit.
Hungary will specialize in and export cars.
Germany will produce more cars than in the absence of trade.
Germany will produce more wheat than in the absence of trade.
answer: Germany will produce more cars than in the absence of trade.

question: A market is a
option: place where only buyers come together.
place where only sellers meet.
group of people with common desires.
group of buyers and sellers of a particular good or service.
answer: group of buyers and sellers of a particular good or service.

question: A monopoly is a market
option: with one seller.
with few sellers.
with one buyer.
where the government sets the price.
answer: with one seller.

question: When we are studying the behavior of buyers, we are studying
option: supply.
demand.
an entire market.
government regulation.
answer: demand.

question: A demand curve is the
option: curve that relates income with quantity demanded.
upward-sloping line relating price with quantity supplied.
downward-sloping line relating the price of the good with the quantity demanded.
None of the above answers is correct.
answer: downward-sloping line relating the price of the good with the quantity demanded.

question: If a good is “normal,” then an increase in income will result in
option: a lower market price.
a decrease in the demand for the good.
an increase in the demand for the good.
no change in the demand for the good.
answer: an increase in the demand for the good.

question: If the price of a substitute to good X increases, then the
option: demand for good X will decrease.
demand for good X will increase.
market price of good X will decrease.
demand for good X will not change.
answer: demand for good X will increase.

question: What will happen in the rice market if buyers are expecting higher prices in the near future?
option: The supply of rice will increase.
The demand for rice will decrease.
The demand for rice will increase.
The demand for rice will be unaffected.
answer: The demand for rice will increase.

question: Ceteris paribus is a Latin phrase that literally means
option: “after this therefore because of this.”
“other things being equal.”
“to respond slowly to a change in price.”
“There’s no such thing as a free lunch.”
answer: “other things being equal.”

question: Which of the following would NOT shift the demand curve for a good or service?
option: a change in income
a change in the price of a related good
a change in the price of the good or service
a change in expectations about the price of the good or service
answer: a change in the price of the good or service

question: If the number of buyers in the market decreases, the
option: demand in the market will decrease.
supply in the market will increase.
demand in the market will increase.
supply in the market will decrease.
answer: demand in the market will decrease.

question: When the price of a good or service changes,
option: supply shifts in the opposite direction.
demand shifts in the opposite direction.
demand shifts in the same direction.
there is a movement along a stable demand curve.
answer: there is a movement along a stable demand curve.

question: A supply curve slopes upward because
option: a decrease in input prices decreases supply.
an increase in input prices increases supply.
as more is produced, per-unit costs of production fall.
an increase in price gives producers incentive to supply a larger quantity.
answer: an increase in price gives producers incentive to supply a larger quantity.

question: A technological advancement will shift the
option: supply curve to the left.
demand curve to the left.
supply curve to the right.
demand curve to the right.
answer: supply curve to the right.

question: Suppose there is an increase in input prices. We would expect supply
option: to increase.
to decrease.
to remain unchanged.
to either increase or decrease.
answer: to decrease.

question: The unique point at which the supply and demand curves intersect is called
option: cohesion.
market unity.
equilibrium.
an agreement.
answer: equilibrium.

question: If there is a shortage of farm laborers, we would expect
option: the wages of farm laborers to increase.
the wages of farm laborers to decrease.
the prices of farm commodities to decrease.
a decrease in the demand for substitutes of farm labor.
answer: the wages of farm laborers to increase.

question: At the equilibrium price
option: sellers would eventually require a higher price.
there will be no pressure on price to rise or fall.
there can still be upward or downward pressure on price.
buyers would not be willing to purchase the output sellers desire to sell.
answer: there will be no pressure on price to rise or fall.

question: When the price is higher than the equilibrium price,
option: a shortage will exist.
quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.
buyers desire to purchase more than is produced.
sellers desire to produce and sell more than buyers wish to purchase.
answer: sellers desire to produce and sell more than buyers wish to purchase.

question: Suppose that demand decreases AND supply decreases. What would you expect to occur in the market for the good?
option: Both equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity would increase.
Equilibrium price would decrease, but the impact on equilibrium quantity would be ambiguous.
Equilibrium quantity would decrease, but the impact on equilibrium price would be ambiguous.
Equilibrium price would increase, but the impact on equilibrium quantity would be ambiguous.
answer: Equilibrium quantity would decrease, but the impact on equilibrium price would be ambiguous.

question: Suppose that the incomes of buyers in a particular market for a normal good declines and there is also a reduction in input prices. What would we expect to occur in this market?
option: Both the equilibrium price and quantity would increase.
Equilibrium price would increase, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.
Equilibrium price would decrease, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.
Equilibrium quantity would increase, but the impact on equilibrium price would be ambiguous.
answer: Equilibrium price would decrease, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.

question: In a free market system, what is the mechanism for rationing scarce resources?
option: the government
prices
buyers
sellers
answer: prices

question: A competitive market is one in which
option: there are so many buyers and sellers that each has a negligible impact on price.
each seller attempts to compete so consumers cannot freely interact with sellers.
the government regulates each seller of the product.
there is only one seller of the product.
answer: there are so many buyers and sellers that each has a negligible impact on price.

question: A monopolistically competitive market is one that consists of
option: a single seller of the product.
a large number of sellers all offering similar but different products.
many buyers and sellers and an identical product.
a few sellers that do not always compete aggressively.
answer: a large number of sellers all offering similar but different products.

question: All of the following are determinants of demand EXCEPT
option: tastes.
income.
technology.
the price of related goods.
answer: technology.

question: If goods X and Y are complements, an increase in the price of X will result in
option: less of good Y sold.
more of good Y sold.
more of good X sold.
no difference in the quantity sold of either good.
answer: less of good Y sold.

question: If Diane receives an increase in her pay, we would expect Diane’s demand for
option: each good she purchases to remain unchanged.
for inferior goods to increase.
for luxury goods to decrease.
for normal goods to increase.
answer: for normal goods to increase.

question: A demand curve illustrates the
option: tradeoff between inflation and unemployment.
positive relationship between price and quantity supplied.
negative relationship between price and quantity demanded.
maximum quantity of two goods an economy is capable of producing with available resources and technology.
answer: negative relationship between price and quantity demanded.

question: Emily tells you that the price of CDs at the music store will be going down next week. You will probably respond by
option: decreasing your current demand for CDs.
increasing your current demand for CDs.
not currently changing your demand for CDs.
refusing to ever buy anymore CDs at that store.
answer: decreasing your current demand for CDs.

question: A market demand curve represents the
option: average demand of all consumers in the market.
vertical sum of all the individual demands for a particular good or service.
wishes of every supplier of a good or service in a particular market.
horizontal sum of all the individual demands for a particular good or service.
answer: horizontal sum of all the individual demands for a particular good or service.

question: The willingness and ability to produce and sell a good or service is called
option: demand.
supply.
equilibrium.
a competitive market.
answer: supply.

question: According to the law of supply, price and quantity supplied are
option: directly related.
inversely related.
independent variables.
the same as the relationship between price and quantity demanded.
answer: directly related.

question: The movement from point A to point B on the graph would be
option: a decrease in quantity supplied.
a decrease in supply.
an increase in supply.
an increase in quantity supplied.
answer: an increase in quantity supplied.

question: A change in which of the following will cause a movement along the supply curve?
option: a change in the state of technology
a change in input prices
a change in the price of the good or service
a change in expectations about future prices
answer: a change in the price of the good or service

question: Bauxite is an important input in the production of aluminum. If the price of bauxite decreases, all else equal, we would expect the supply of
option: aluminum to be unaffected.
aluminum to decrease.
aluminum to increase.
bauxite to increase.
answer: aluminum to increase.

question: An improvement in the state of technology in production will result in
option: an increase in equilibrium price and an increase in equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in equilibrium price and a decrease in equilibrium quantity.
an increase in equilibrium price and no change in equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in equilibrium price and an increase in equilibrium quantity.
answer: a decrease in equilibrium price and an increase in equilibrium quantity.

question: The price where quantity supplied equals quantity demanded is called the
option: equilibrium price.
monopoly price.
coordinating price.
All of the above are correct.
answer: equilibrium price.

question: At the equilibrium price,
option: everyone in the market has been satisfied.
it is possible for there to be a shortage.
firms have an incentive to increase production.
buyers have an incentive to buy more.
answer: everyone in the market has been satisfied.

question: If a market is currently experiencing a shortage at the current price, then
option: the market must be in equilibrium.
the price is below the equilibrium price.
quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.
sellers are producing more than buyers wish to buy because the price is too high.
answer: the price is below the equilibrium price.

question: Suppose oranges are currently selling for $2.00 per pound. The equilibrium price of oranges is $1.56 per pound. We would expect a
option: shortage to exist and the market price of oranges to increase.
shortage to exist and the market price of oranges to decrease.
surplus to exist and the market price of oranges to increase.
surplus to exist and the market price of oranges to decrease.
answer: surplus to exist and the market price of oranges to decrease.

question: Suppose that the incomes of buyers in a particular market for a normal good declines and there is also a reduction in input prices. What would we expect to occur in this market?
option: The equilibrium price would increase, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.
The equilibrium price would decrease, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.
Both equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity would increase.
Equilibrium quantity would increase, but the impact on equilibrium price would be ambiguous.
answer: The equilibrium price would decrease, but the impact on the amount sold in the market would be ambiguous.

question: A stronger demand together with a weaker supply would necessarily result in
option: a lower price.
a higher price.
an increase in equilibrium quantity.
a decrease in equilibrium quantity.
answer: a higher price.

question: In a free market system, what coordinates the actions of millions of people with their varying abilities and desires?
option: producers
consumers
prices
the government
answer: prices

question: In general, elasticity is
option: a measure of the competitive nature of a market.
the friction that develops between buyer and seller in a market.
a measure of how much government intervention is prevalent in a market.
a measure of how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.
answer: a measure of how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.

question: Demand is said to be elastic if
option: the price of the good responds substantially to changes in demand.
the quantity demanded responds substantially to changes in the price of the good.
buyers don’t respond much to changes in the price of the good.
demand shifts substantially when the price of the good changes.
answer: the quantity demanded responds substantially to changes in the price of the good.

question: Demand for a good would tend to be more elastic, the
option: longer the period of time considered.
greater the availability of complements.
broader the definition of the market.
fewer substitutes there are.
answer: longer the period of time considered.

question: Economists compute the price elasticity of demand as
option: percentage change in the price divided by the percentage change in quantity demanded.
change in quantity demanded divided by the change in the price.
percentage change in the quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price.
percentage change in the quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income.
answer: percentage change in the quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price.

question: If there are very few, if any, good substitutes for good A, then
option: supply of good A would tend to be price elastic.
demand for good A would tend to be price inelastic.
demand for good A would tend to be price elastic.
demand for good A would tend to be income elastic.
answer: demand for good A would tend to be price inelastic.

question: Suppose the price of product X is reduced from $1.45 to $1.25 and, as a result, the quantity of X demanded increases from 2,000 to 2,200. Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand for X in the given price range is
The main reason for using the midpoint method is that it
option: uses fewer numbers.
rounds prices to the nearest dollar.
gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.
rounds quantities to the nearest whole unit.
answer: gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.

question: If the demand curve is linear and downward sloping, which of the following would NOT be correct?
option: Elasticity will change with a movement down the curve.
The upper part of the demand curve is more elastic than the lower part.
The lower part of the demand curve would be less elastic than the upper part.
Elasticity and slope would both remain constant along the curve.
answer: Elasticity and slope would both remain constant along the curve.

question: Demand is elastic if elasticity is
option: equal to 0.
equal to 1.
less than 1.
greater than 1.
answer: greater than 1.

question: A perfectly elastic demand implies that
option: buyers will not respond to any change in price.
price and quantity demanded respond proportionally.
price will rise by an infinite amount when there is a change in quantity demanded.
any rise in price above that represented by the demand curve will result in no output demanded.
answer: any rise in price above that represented by the demand curve will result in no output demanded.

question: On a downward-sloping, linear demand curve, total revenue would be at a maximum at the
option: upper end of the demand curve.
midpoint of the demand curve.
lower end of the demand curve.
It is impossible to tell without knowing the price and quantity demanded.
answer: midpoint of the demand curve.

question: When demand is inelastic, a decrease in price will cause
option: no change in total revenue.
an increase in total revenue.
a decrease in total revenue.
There is insufficient information to answer this question.
answer: a decrease in total revenue.

question: The local pizza restaurant makes such great bread sticks that consumers do not respond much to a change in the price. If the owner is only interested in increasing revenue, he should
option: reduce costs.
lower the price of the bread sticks.
raise the price of the bread sticks.
leave the price of the bread sticks alone.
answer: raise the price of the bread sticks.

question: If a change in the price of a good results in no change in total revenue,
option: the demand for the good must be elastic.
the demand for the good must be unit elastic.
the demand for the good must be inelastic.
buyers must not respond very much to a change in price.
answer: the demand for the good must be unit elastic.

question: Assume that a 4 percent increase in income results in a 2 percent increase in the quantity demanded of a good. The income elasticity of demand for the good is
option: positive and therefore the good is a normal good.
negative and therefore the good is an inferior good.
negative and therefore the good is a normal good.
positive and therefore the good is an inferior good.
answer: positive and therefore the good is a normal good.

question: Cross-price elasticity of demand measures how the
option: quantity demanded of a good changes as price changes.
quantity demanded of a good changes as income changes.
price of a good is affected when income changes.
quantity demanded of one good changes as the price of another good changes.
answer: quantity demanded of one good changes as the price of another good changes.

question: The price elasticity of supply measures how much
option: the quantity supplied responds to changes in the price of the good.
the quantity supplied responds to changes in input prices.
the price of the good responds to changes in supply.
sellers respond to changes in technology.
answer: the quantity supplied responds to changes in the price of the good.

question: The main determinant of the price elasticity of supply is
option: time.
luxuries vs. necessities.
the definition of the market.
the number of close substitutes.
answer: time.

question: Suppose that an increase in the price of carrots from $1.20 to $1.40 per pound raises the amount of carrots that carrot farmers are willing to supply from 1.2 million pounds to 1.6 million pounds. Using the midpoint method, what would be the elasticity of supply?
If the elasticity of supply of a product is greater than 1, then supply is
option: inelastic.
elastic.
unit elastic.
not very sensitive to change in price.
answer: elastic.

question: Supply tends to be
option: less price elastic in the long run.
perfectly price inelastic in the long run.
more price elastic in the long run.
perfectly price inelastic in the long run.
answer: more price elastic in the long run.

question: A vertical supply curve signifies that
option: an infinite quantity will be supplied at a given price.
a change in price will have no effect on quantity supplied.
the relationship between price and quantity supplied is inverse.
a change in price will change quantity supplied in the opposite direction.
answer: a change in price will have no effect on quantity supplied.

question: Suppose a producer is able to separate customers into two groups, one having a price inelastic demand and the other having a price elastic demand. If the producer’s objective is to increase total revenue, she should
option: charge the same price to both groups of customers.
increase the price for both groups of customers.
increase the price charged to customers with the price elastic demand and decrease the price charged to customers with the price inelastic demand.
decrease the price charged to customers with the price elastic demand and increase the price charged to customers with the price inelastic demand.
answer: decrease the price charged to customers with the price elastic demand and increase the price charged to customers with the price inelastic demand.

question: The elasticity of demand measures
option: the increase in demand as additional buyers enter the market.
a buyer’s responsiveness to a change in the price of a good.
how much less of a good consumers will demand when incomes fall.
the increase in supply that will occur from an increase in the price of a good.
answer: a buyer’s responsiveness to a change in the price of a good.

question: Demand is said to be inelastic if
option: consumers hardly respond to a change in price.
consumers respond substantially to a change in price.
consumers respond directly to a change in income.
the change in quantity demanded is equal to the change in price.
answer: consumers hardly respond to a change in price.

question: The elasticity of demand for luxuries tends to be
option: greater than 1.
equal to 1.
less than 1.
equal to 0.
answer: less than 1.

question: Milky Way candy bars tend to have an elastic demand because
option: the candy bar market is too broadly defined.
there are many close substitutes for Milky Ways.
Milky Ways are considered by some to be a necessity.
it is usually eaten quickly and therefore the time horizon is short.
answer: there are many close substitutes for Milky Ways.

question: Economists compute elasticity using the midpoint method primarily because it
option: is the simplest method to compute elasticity.
uses the same equation that is used to compute slope.
automatically rounds quantities to the nearest whole unit.
gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.
answer: gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.

question: Demand is elastic if elasticity is
option: equal to 1.
equal to 0.
less than 1.
greater than 1.
answer: greater than 1.

question: A demand curve that is a downward-sloping straight line will have
option: a positive slope.
higher elasticity at the top than at the bottom.
lower elasticity at the top than at the bottom.
constant elasticity throughout its length.
answer: higher elasticity at the top than at the bottom.

question: When the price of Pokemon cards are $.50, the quantity demanded is 400 cards per day. When the price falls to $.40, the quantity demanded increases to 600. Given this information and using the midpoint method, you know that the demand for Pokemon cards is
option: elastic.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
perfectly inelastic.
answer: elastic.

question: A perfectly inelastic demand is
option: vertical because buyers purchase the same amount whether the price rises or falls.
negatively sloped because buyers decrease their purchases when the price rises.
positively sloped because buyers respond by increasing their purchases when price rises.
horizontal because buyers increase their purchases by huge amounts with slight changes in price.
answer: vertical because buyers purchase the same amount whether the price rises or falls.

question: Total revenue changes as one moves down a linear demand curve by
option: decreasing.
increasing.
decreasing, then increasing.
increasing, then decreasing.
answer: increasing, then decreasing.

question: If the demand for bagels is elastic, an increase in the price of bagels will
option: increase total revenue of bagel sellers.
decrease total revenue of bagel sellers.
not change total revenue of bagel sellers.
There is not enough information to answer this question.
answer: decrease total revenue of bagel sellers.

question: Corporation XYZ has a linear demand curve for its product. The company is currently producing on the lower portion of its demand curve. Increasing the price of the product will
option: not affect the company’s total revenue.
increase the company’s total revenue.
decrease the company’s total revenue.
increase the company’s total cost of production.
answer: increase the company’s total revenue.

question: When a change in the price of a good results in no change in total revenue you know that the demand for this product is
option: elastic.
perfectly inelastic.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
answer: unit elastic.

question: If a 6 percent increase in income results in a 3 percent decrease in the quantity demanded of macaroni, then the income elasticity of demand for macaroni is
option: negative and therefore macaroni is an inferior good.
negative and therefore macaroni is a normal good.
positive and therefore macaroni is an inferior good.
positive and therefore macaroni is a normal good.
answer: negative and therefore macaroni is an inferior good.

question: The cross-price elasticity of demand determines whether goods are
option: normal or inferior.
elastic or inelastic.
luxuries or necessities.
complements or substitutes.
answer: complements or substitutes.

question: The price elasticity of supply measures how responsive
option: sellers are to a change in price.
buyers are to a change in price.
buyers are to a change in income.
sellers are to a change in buyers’ income.
answer: sellers are to a change in price.

question: The price elasticity of supply for a good will be greater (more elastic) the
option: more necessary the good is considered.
broader the market is defined.
more close substitutes the good has.
longer the time period being considered.
answer: longer the time period being considered.

question: If two supply curves pass through the same point and one is steep and the other is flat, which of the following would be correct?
option: The flatter supply curve is more elastic.
The steeper supply curve is more elastic.
The elasticity of supply will be the same for both curves.
It is impossible to tell the elasticity of supply for either curve unless you are given actual numbers to compute the elasticity of both curves.
answer: The flatter supply curve is more elastic.

question: A vertical supply curve tells us that
option: suppliers will not respond to a change in price.
an infinite quantity will be supplied at a given price.
suppliers will refuse to sell the product at the current market price.
if the price of the product increases quantity supplied will decrease substantially.
answer: suppliers will not respond to a change in price.

question: If the elasticity of supply of a product is 0.5, then we know that supply is
option: elastic.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
perfectly inelastic.
answer: inelastic.

question: Knowing that the demand for wheat is inelastic, if wheat farmers wanted to increase their total revenue they should all
option: plant more wheat so that they would be able to sell more each year.
increase spending on fertilizer in an attempt to produce more on the acres they farm.
voluntarily plow under a certain percent of their wheat crop to raise the price.
advertise in an attempt to get consumers to buy more wheat.
answer: voluntarily plow under a certain percent of their wheat crop to raise the price.

question: A firm would be willing to supply 500 frisbees per day at a price of $3.00 each. At a price of $5.00 each the firm would be willing to supply 1100 frisbees. Using the midpoint method, the elasticity of supply would be
You have just been hired as a business consultant to determine what pricing policy would be appropriate in order to increase the total revenue of a clothing store. The first step you would take is to
option: increase the prices of the store’s products.
look for ways to cut costs and increase profit for the store.
determine the elasticity of demand for the store’s products.
suggest that the store purchase an entirely new line of clothing that they could sell more cheaply.
answer: determine the elasticity of demand for the store’s products.

question: “A number of mass transit systems have been experiencing declining revenues despite fare increases.” Assuming that the demand for mass transit has not changed (i.e., that the demand curve has not shifted), the above statement implies that
option: the demand for mass transit is elastic with respect to price.
the demand for mass transit is inelastic with respect to price.
mass transit is an inferior good.
revenues would have risen only if fares had been increased by a larger amount.
answer: the demand for mass transit is elastic with respect to price.

question: Price controls are
option: established by firms with monopoly power.
used to make markets more efficient.
nearly always effective in eliminating inequities.
usually enacted when policymakers believe that the market price of a good or service is unfair to buyers or sellers.
answer: usually enacted when policymakers believe that the market price of a good or service is unfair to buyers or sellers.

question: A legal minimum price at which a good can be sold is a price
option: cut.
floor.
ceiling.
stabilization.
answer: floor.

question: If a price ceiling is a binding constraint on the market,
option: the forces of supply and demand must be in equilibrium.
the equilibrium price must be below the price ceiling.
the equilibrium price must be above the price ceiling.
it will have no effect on supply or demand.
answer: the equilibrium price must be above the price ceiling.

question: A binding price ceiling is imposed on the market for peaches. At the ceiling price, the quantity demanded of peaches will be
option: greater than the quantity supplied.
smaller than the quantity supplied.
equal to the quantity supplied.
artificially restricted by the price ceiling.
answer: greater than the quantity supplied.

question: A binding price ceiling will make it necessary to
option: supply more of the product.
increase demand for the product, because there will be a surplus.
develop a better marketing plan, because there will be a surplus.
develop a way of rationing the product, because there will be a shortage.
answer: develop a way of rationing the product, because there will be a shortage.

question: A price floor is binding if it is
option: set by the government.
higher than the equilibrium market price.
lower than the equilibrium market price.
equal to the equilibrium market price.
answer: higher than the equilibrium market price.

question: The minimum wage is an example of
option: a price floor.
a price ceiling.
a free-market process.
an efficient labor allocation mechanism.
answer: a price floor.

question: If the minimum wage is above the equilibrium wage,
option: anyone who wants a job at the minimum wage can find one.
the quantity demanded of labor will be greater than the quantity supplied.
the quantity demanded of labor will equal the quantity supplied.
the quantity demanded of labor will be less than the quantity supplied.
answer: the quantity demanded of labor will be less than the quantity supplied.

question: The term tax incidence refers to the
option: Boston Tea Party.
“flat tax” movement.
division of the tax burden between sales taxes and income taxes.
division of the tax burden between buyers and sellers.
answer: division of the tax burden between buyers and sellers.

question: A tax on the buyers of popcorn
option: reduces the size of the popcorn market.
increases the size of the popcorn market.
has no effect on the size of the popcorn market.
may increase, decrease, or have no effect on the size of the popcorn market.
answer: reduces the size of the popcorn market.

question: A tax on the sellers of popcorn
option: causes the supply curve to shift to the right.
leads sellers to supply a smaller quantity at every price.
leads buyers to demand a smaller quantity at every price.
leads sellers to supply a larger quantity at every price.
answer: leads sellers to supply a smaller quantity at every price.

question: A tax of $.10 per bag on the sellers of popcorn will cause the
option: supply curve of popcorn to shift up by $.10 per bag.
supply curve of popcorn to shift down by $.05 per bag.
demand curve of popcorn to shift up by $.10 per bag.
supply curve of popcorn to shift down by $.10 per bag.
answer: supply curve of popcorn to shift up by $.10 per bag.

question: A tax on the sellers of popcorn will
option: reduce the equilibrium price of popcorn, and increase the equilibrium quantity.
reduce the equilibrium price of popcorn, and reduce the equilibrium quantity.
increase the equilibrium price of popcorn, and reduce the equilibrium quantity.
increase the equilibrium price of popcorn, and increase the equilibrium quantity.
answer: increase the equilibrium price of popcorn, and reduce the equilibrium quantity.

question: A tax on the sellers of popcorn will cause the price the buyers pay
option: and the effective price the sellers receive to rise.
and the effective price the sellers receive to fall.
to fall, and the price the sellers receive to rise.
to rise, and the effective price the sellers receive to fall.
answer: to rise, and the effective price the sellers receive to fall.

question: What is true about the burden of a tax imposed on popcorn?
option: Sellers bear the entire burden of the tax.
Buyers bear the entire burden of the tax.
Buyers and sellers share the burden of the tax.
The government bears the entire burden of the tax.
answer: Buyers and sellers share the burden of the tax.

question: The key feature of a payroll tax is that it
option: is a tax on corporations.
is a tax on poor people.
does not affect equilibrium in labor markets.
places a wedge between the wage that firms pay and the wage that workers receive.
answer: places a wedge between the wage that firms pay and the wage that workers receive.

question: If a tax is imposed on a market with inelastic demand and elastic supply,
option: sellers will bear most of the burden of the tax.
buyers will bear most of the burden of the tax.
the burden of the tax will be shared equally between buyers and sellers.
it is impossible to determine how the burden of the tax will be shared.
answer: buyers will bear most of the burden of the tax.

question: Which of the following is the most correct statement about tax burdens?
option: A tax burden falls most heavily on the side of the market that is closer to unit elastic.
A tax burden is distributed independently of relative elasticities of supply and demand.
A tax burden falls most heavily on the side of the market that is elastic.
A tax burden falls most heavily on the side of the market that is inelastic.
answer: A tax burden falls most heavily on the side of the market that is inelastic.

question: When policymakers choose to enact price controls in a market, they do so because
option: they believe the market’s outcome to be unfair.
enacting price controls will directly increase tax revenues.
they are required by law to improve market conditions.
they believe that the market system is inefficient and their actions will improve efficiency.
answer: they believe the market’s outcome to be unfair.

question: A government-imposed maximum price at which a good can be sold is called a price
option: floor.
ceiling.
support.
equilibrium.
answer: ceiling.

question: If a price ceiling is not binding, it will
option: cause a surplus in the market.
cause a shortage in the market.
cause the market price to fluctuate.
have no effect on the market price.
answer: have no effect on the market price.

question: If a binding price ceiling is imposed in the market for gasoline,
option: there will be a surplus of gasoline in the market.
the price of gasoline will be legally forced toward equilibrium price.
there will be a shortage of gasoline in the market.
market forces will guarantee that the price will be at equilibrium.
answer: there will be a shortage of gasoline in the market.

question: A common example of a price ceiling is
option: farm price supports.
the minimum wage.
rent control.
income taxes.
answer: rent control.

question: Price controls such as price ceilings and price floors
option: are desirable because they make markets more efficient as well as equitable.
cause surpluses and shortages to persist since price cannot adjust to the market equilibrium price.
can be enacted to restore a market to equilibrium.
are imposed because they can make the poor in the economy better off without causing adverse effects.
answer: cause surpluses and shortages to persist since price cannot adjust to the market equilibrium price.

question: If the government establishes a legal price floor for a good, the result will be a
option: shortage of the good, but only if the floor is equal to the equilibrium price.
surplus of the good, but only if the floor is above the equilibrium price.
surplus of the good, but only if the floor is below the equilibrium price.
shortage of the good, but only if the floor is above the equilibrium price.
answer: surplus of the good, but only if the floor is above the equilibrium price.

question: When minimum wage laws are established, employers must
option: pay the going (equilibrium) wage in the market.
pay a wage equal to, or higher than, the minimum wage.
hire a minimum number of employees, which is set by the government.
hire only those workers who will work for the established minimum wage..
answer: pay a wage equal to, or higher than, the minimum wage.

question: Tax incidence deals with
option: the level of taxable income.
who bears the burden of a tax.
the level of taxation on sales.
the dollar amount of incidental taxes.
answer: who bears the burden of a tax.

question: A tax placed on the buyers of a product will
option: reduce the equilibrium price and increase the equilibrium quantity of that product.
reduce the equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity of that product.
increase the equilibrium price and equilibrium quantity of that product.
increase the equilibrium price and reduce the equilibrium quantity of that product.
answer: increase the equilibrium price and reduce the equilibrium quantity of that product.

question: When a tax is imposed on the buyers of a product, the burden of the tax falls
option: entirely on the buyers.
entirely on the sellers.
entirely on the government.
on both the buyers and the sellers.
answer: on both the buyers and the sellers.

question: A tax placed on the sellers of a product has an initial impact on
option: the supply of the product.
the demand for the product.
both the product supply and demand.
Taxes do not impact demand and supply.
answer: the supply of the product.

question: Payroll taxes cause wages received by workers to
option: fall and wages paid by firms to rise.
fall and wages paid by firms to fall.
rise and wage paid by firms to fall.
rise and wage paid by firms to rise.
answer: fall and wages paid by firms to rise.

question: In the final analysis, tax incidence is determined by
option: the size of the tax imposed.
the forces of supply and demand.
trial and error.
the policymakers who wrote the tax law.
answer: the forces of supply and demand.

question: Buyers of a product will pay most of the burden of a tax if
option: supply is more elastic than demand.
the demand is more elastic than supply.
the tax is placed on the seller of the product.
the tax is placed on the buyer of the product.
answer: supply is more elastic than demand.
