more than is market optimal.
answer: less than is socially desirable.

question: Internalizing a positive production externality through a government subsidy will cause industry supply to
option: remain unchanged.
increase by an amount equal to the subsidy.
increase by an amount less than the subsidy.
decrease by an amount greater than the subsidy.
answer: increase by an amount equal to the subsidy.

question: A positive consumption externality occurs when
option: Jack’s consumption is not beneficial to John.
Jack receives personal benefits from his own consumption of a certain good.
Jack’s benefit exceeds John’s benefit when they each consume the same good.
Jack receives a benefit from John’s consumption of a certain good.
answer: Jack receives a benefit from John’s consumption of a certain good.

question: A negative consumption externality will cause a private market to produce
option: more than is socially desirable.
less than is socially desirable.
less than is market optimal.
the socially desirable quantity.
answer: more than is socially desirable.

question: When dealing with externalities, the market equilibrium can be moved closer to the social equilibrium by
option: taxing negative externalities and subsidizing positive externalities.
taxing both positive and negative externalities.
subsidizing both positive and negative externalities.
None of the above, because government has no corrective policy with regards to consumption externalities.
answer: taxing negative externalities and subsidizing positive externalities.

question: Firms that are involved in different types of business could be evidence of an attempt to
option: increase private profit at the expense of consumers.
internalize some forms of positive externalities.
increase the marginal external cost of production.
reduce the impact of government regulation on their business.
answer: internalize some forms of positive externalities.

question: All remedies for externalities share the goal of
option: increasing the allocation of resources.
decreasing the allocation of resources.
moving the allocation of resources toward the market equilibrium.
moving the allocation of resources toward the social optimum.
answer: moving the allocation of resources toward the social optimum.

question: Dick owns a dog whose barking annoys Dick’s neighbor Jane. Suppose that the benefit of owning the dog is worth $500 to Dick and that Jane bears a cost of $700 from the barking. Assuming Dick has the legal right to keep the dog, a possible private solution to this problem is that
option: Jane pays Dick $650 to get rid of the dog.
Dick pays Jane $650 for her inconvenience.
Jane pays Dick $500 to get rid of the dog.
There is no private solution that would improve this situation.
answer: Jane pays Dick $650 to get rid of the dog.

question: Which of the following is true of the Coase theorem ?
option: The bargain outcome will be inefficient.
Interested parties can reach an outcome in which everyone is better off.
Interested parties will need an arbitrator in order to reach an agreement that is efficient.
Government intervention is necessary to solve the problem of externalities.
answer: Interested parties can reach an outcome in which everyone is better off.

question: Employing a lawyer to draft and enforce a private contract between parties wishing to solve an externality problem is an example of
option: a sunk cost.
an implicit cost.
a transaction cost.
an opportunity cost.
answer: a transaction cost.

question: Pigovian taxes
option: are rarely preferred to direct regulation.
are frequently used to discourage imports.
encourage consumers to avoid sales taxes by shopping on-line.
give factory owners an economic incentive to reduce pollution.
answer: give factory owners an economic incentive to reduce pollution.

question: A Pigovian tax
option: is a form of regulation.
allocates pollution to those factories that face the highest cost of reducing it.
works well for all types of externalities.
is deemed inferior to regulatory policy by most economists.
answer: allocates pollution to those factories that face the highest cost of reducing it.

question: In some cases, pollution permits may be better than a Pigovian tax because
option: the government can set a maximum level of pollution using permits.
pollution permits allow for a market solution while a Pigovian tax does not.
pollution permits are never preferred over a Pigovian tax.
pollution permits generate more revenue for the government than a Pigovian tax.
answer: the government can set a maximum level of pollution using permits.

question: Which of the following is NOT true concerning tradable pollution permits?
option: Tradable pollution permits are a scarce resource.
Tradable pollution permits can be traded in a market governed by supply and demand.
Tradable pollution permits eventually lead to an efficient elimination of all pollution.
Tradable pollution permits will be sold by firms that can reduce pollution at low costs.
answer: Tradable pollution permits eventually lead to an efficient elimination of all pollution.

question: Which of the following policies is government most inclined to use when faced with a positive externality?
option: permits
taxation
subsidies
usage fees
answer: subsidies

question: Externalities occur when
option: one person’s actions affect the well-being of a bystander.
the government imposes taxes.
increases in the price of oil cause gasoline prices to rise.
higher wages result in increased spending.
answer: one person’s actions affect the well-being of a bystander.

question: Private markets fail to account for externalities because
option: externalities don’t occur in private markets.
sellers include any costs associated with externalities in the price of their product.
decision makers in the market fail to take into account the external effects of their behavior.
the government can easily correct any adverse effect externalities may have on the market.
answer: decision makers in the market fail to take into account the external effects of their behavior.

question: A beekeeper places his hives of bees in an orchard so that the bees can gather nectar to produce honey. As a result, the bees pollinate the orchard which increases the yield of fruit and also causes
option: a positive externality that benefits only the beekeeper.
a negative externality since the bees are a hazard to the orchard owner.
a positive externality that benefits only the owner of the orchard.
positive externalities that benefit both the beekeeper and the orchard owner.
answer: positive externalities that benefit both the beekeeper and the orchard owner.

question: When negative production externalities are present in a market
option: private costs will be greater than social costs.
social costs will be greater than private costs.
government regulation to resolve the problem is necessary.
the market will not be able to reach any equilibrium situation.
answer: social costs will be greater than private costs.

question: A fertilizer plant emits a very foul odor (a negative externality) during the production process. If the government forces the plant to internalize the externality, then the
option: supply curve for fertilizer would shift to the right (down).
supply curve for fertilizer would shift to the left (up).
demand curve for fertilizer would shift to the right (up).
demand curve for fertilizer would shift to the left (down).
answer: supply curve for fertilizer would shift to the left (up).

question: When a market experiences a positive consumption externality,
option: the demand curve does not reflect the value to society of the good.
too much of the good is being produced.
the government can internalize the externality by imposing a tax on the product.
the private value is greater than the social value.
answer: the demand curve does not reflect the value to society of the good.

question: Internalizing an externality refers to
option: the fact that sellers only consider their private costs when making a decision.
the fact that buyers only consider their private benefits when making a decision.
altering incentives so people consider the external effects of their actions when making a decision.
government establishing agencies such as the Environmental Protection Agency to enforce regulations.
answer: altering incentives so people consider the external effects of their actions when making a decision.

question: The government can internalize a positive production externality by
option: taxing production which would decrease supply.
taxing production which would increase supply.
subsidizing production which would decrease supply.
subsidizing production which would increase supply.
answer: subsidizing production which would increase supply.

question: Technology spillover means that
option: it is the government’s responsibility to subsidize firms which are engaged in high-tech research.
a firm’s research yields technological knowledge that can then be used by society as a whole.
those firms engaged in technology research may be taxed by the government if that research causes negative externalities in the market.
when firms invest in the latest production technology, the cost of that technology ‘spills over’ to the prices consumers must pay for the product.
answer: a firm’s research yields technological knowledge that can then be used by society as a whole.

question: When a market experiences a positive production externality, we can expect a
option: smaller market output and a higher market price than optimal.
greater market output and lower market price than optimal.
greater market output and higher market price than optimal.
smaller market output and lower market price than optimal.
answer: smaller market output and a higher market price than optimal.

question: If the government wanted to ensure the market reaches the social optimum in the presence of a technology spillover, it should
option: impose a Pigovian tax on any firm producing a technology spillover.
offer tax credits to consumers that are adversely affected by the new technology.
subsidize producers by an amount equal to the value of the technology spillover.
provide research grants to those firms not currently engaging in research to increase competition in the industry.
answer: subsidize producers by an amount equal to the value of the technology spillover.

question: When production externalities exist, policymakers can sometimes improve market outcomes by
option: taxing both positive and negative externalities.
subsidizing both positive and negative externalities.
taxing negative externalities and subsidizing positive externalities.
taxing positive externalities and subsidizing negative externalities.
answer: taxing negative externalities and subsidizing positive externalities.

question: When action is taken to remedy externalities, the goal is to
option: increase total production in the economy.
move the allocation of resources closer to the social optimum.
eliminate the externalities without affecting market outcomes.
hold the government accountable for eliminating these market failures.
answer: move the allocation of resources closer to the social optimum.

question: The Coase theorem suggests that private markets may not be able to solve the problem of externalities
option: when the number of interested parties is large and costs are high.
if government does not become actively involved in the process.
if the firm in the market is a monopoly.
when market participants do not want the externality to be eliminated.
answer: when the number of interested parties is large and costs are high.

question: Roger enjoys an oak tree in his yard, but its leaves blow onto his neighbor Nancy’s yard each fall which she must clean up. If the benefit of the tree is worth $400 to Roger and the cost to Nancy of the tree is $600, which of the following statements would be true?
option: Nancy can pay Roger $200 to get rid of the tree.
Roger can pay Nancy $500 for her inconvenience.
Nancy can pay Roger $500 to get rid of the tree.
There is no private solution that would improve this situation.
answer: Nancy can pay Roger $500 to get rid of the tree.

question: Private solutions may not always be possible if negotiating and enforcing these solutions involve high
option: Pigovian taxes.
opportunity costs.
deadweight losses.
transaction costs.
answer: transaction costs.

question: If only a few people are affected by an externality, then it is likely that
option: Pigovian taxes will provide the most efficient solution to the externality.
command-and-control regulation will provide the most efficient solution to the externality.
a private solution to the inefficiency will occur.
a private solution will be very difficult to negotiate.
answer: a private solution to the inefficiency will occur.

question: Emission controls on automobiles is an example of a
option: Pigovian tax on automobiles, based on how much they pollute.
command-and-control policy to increase social efficiency.
policy that reduces pollution by allocating resources through market mechanisms.
policy to reduce congestion on urban freeways.
answer: command-and-control policy to increase social efficiency.

question: A Pigovian tax is a tax
option: that will move the market away from the optimum quantity.
on pollution regulations.
that is enacted to correct the effects of a negative externality.
that special interest groups lobby for in order to decrease the cost of producing goods and services.
answer: that is enacted to correct the effects of a negative externality.

question: A comparison between a Pigovian tax and tradable pollution permits shows that
option: both policies will effectively eliminate a positive externality in a market.
a Pigovian tax sets the price of pollution where pollution permits set the quantity of pollution.
levying a Pigovian tax is always preferable to issuing pollution permits.
a Pigovian tax fixes the acceptable pollution quantity where pollution permits allow for increases in pollution levels.
answer: a Pigovian tax sets the price of pollution where pollution permits set the quantity of pollution.

question: When one firm sells its pollution permit to another firm, each of the following will occur EXCEPT
option: both firms benefit.
social welfare is enhanced.
government revenue increases.
the total amount of pollution remains the same.
answer: government revenue increases.

question: What should policymakers do if they wish to encourage production (such as medical research) that provides a positive externality?
option: place taxes on the sale of prescription drugs
provide subsidies to firms engaged in medical research
impose years of trials and testing on selected medical procedures
ensure only the most qualified researchers are employed by issuing licenses to work at these firms
answer: provide subsidies to firms engaged in medical research

question: A good is excludable if
option: it is not a normal good.
people can be prevented from using it.
the government regulates its availability.
one person’s use of the good diminishes another person’s enjoyment of it.
answer: people can be prevented from using it.

question: If one person’s use of a good diminishes another person’s enjoyment of it, the good is
option: rival.
normal.
excludable.
exhaustible.
answer: rival.

question: Goods that are nonexcludable and nonrival are
option: common resources.
natural monopolies.
private goods.
public goods.
answer: public goods.

question: The market does not provide national defense because
option: the fixed cost of national defense is too high.
the resources to operate national defense are not available in the private sector.
it is impossible to prevent any single person from enjoying the benefit of national defense.
all of the above
answer: it is impossible to prevent any single person from enjoying the benefit of national defense.

question: The fish in the ocean are an example of a
option: private good.
public good.
common resource.
natural monopoly good.
answer: common resource.

question: Due to the externalities associated with public goods and common resources,
option: private markets will lead to an efficient allocation of resources.
private markets will correct for the gain or loss in consumer surplus.
government intervention can potentially raise economic well-being.
all of the above
answer: government intervention can potentially raise economic well-being.

question: Market failure associated with the free-rider problem is a result of
option: a problem associated with pollution.
a project in which costs exceed benefits.
losses that accrue to providers of the product.
benefits that accrue to those who don’t pay.
answer: benefits that accrue to those who don’t pay.

question: Basic research is a public good because it
option: is a rival good.
is difficult to exclude those who might benefit from it.
is used to develop public goods.
always benefits developed countries at the expense of developing countries.
answer: is difficult to exclude those who might benefit from it.

question: If everyone benefits from helping the poor,
option: taxing the wealthy to raise the living standards of the poor can potentially make everyone better off.
government intervention can only make things worse.
eliminating taxes aimed at redistributing income will necessarily make rich people better off.
private markets can adequately provide charity programs to help the poor despite free-rider problems.
answer: taxing the wealthy to raise the living standards of the poor can potentially make everyone better off.

question: A lighthouse is typically considered a good example of a public good because
option: there is rarely another lighthouse nearby to provide competition.
all passing ships are able to enjoy the benefits of the lighthouse without paying.
a nearby port authority cannot avoid paying fees to the lighthouse owner.
the owner of the lighthouse is able to exclude beneficiaries from enjoying the lighthouse.
answer: all passing ships are able to enjoy the benefits of the lighthouse without paying.

question: Which of the following suggests that individuals do not place an infinite value on human life?
option: sky-diving
road intersections without stop signs
cars that are manufactured and purchased without the latest safety features
all of the above
answer: all of the above

question: Some goods can be either common resources or public goods depending on
option: the marginal cost of the good.
whether the good is rival.
how policymakers deal with the good.
none of the above.
answer: whether the good is rival.

question: One way to eliminate the Tragedy of the Commons is to
option: limit access to the commons.
increase access to the commons.
increase law enforcement in public areas.
provide more public land for recreation.
answer: limit access to the commons.

question: Overuse of common resources can potentially be resolved by governments that
option: subsidize use.
deregulate use.
convert the common resource to a private good.
all of the above
answer: convert the common resource to a private good.

question: If a road is congested, then use of that road by an additional person would lead to a
option: positive externality.
negative externality.
natural monopoly problem.
free-rider problem with rush hour drivers stuck in traffic.
answer: negative externality.

question: In an attempt to improve the pollution problem outside the central city of Singapore, the Singapore government
option: charges a premium tax on gasoline.
allows only motorcycle and bicycle transportation.
auctions off the right to license new cars.
does not allow taxis to travel outside the central city.
answer: auctions off the right to license new cars.

question: Excessive fishing occurs because
option: fishermen have other marketable skills and do not fear exploitation of fish reserves.
fishermen rely on government managers to worry about fish populations.
each individual fisherman has little incentive to maintain the species for the next year.
fishermen are concerned about the population dynamics of fish biomass, not current harvest rates.
answer: each individual fisherman has little incentive to maintain the species for the next year.

question: The U.S. government protects fish by
option: subsidizing the fishing industry.
heavily taxing competing industries.
increasing taxes on fishing poles and lures.
selling fishing licenses and regulating fish lengths.
answer: selling fishing licenses and regulating fish lengths.

question: Why do elephants face the threat of extinction while cows do not?
option: There is a high demand for products that come only from the cow.
Cattle are owned by ranchers, while elephants are owned by no one.
There are still lots of cattle that roam free, while most elephants are in zoos.
Cattle are a valuable source of income for many people and elephants have no market value.
answer: Cattle are owned by ranchers, while elephants are owned by no one.

question: A good solution to saving the tiger from extinction would be to
option: tax the sale of tiger hides.
outlaw the sale of tigers or any part of them.
give the tigers’ habitat to someone.
regulate the traditional use of Asian medicines that use tiger liver.
answer: give the tigers’ habitat to someone.

question: To most economists, the best solution to the overcrowding problem at Yellowstone National park is to
option: increase financial aid from the government.
place daily quotas on the number of vehicles that enter the park.
increase entrance fees to the park.
temporarily close down damaged sections of the park.
answer: increase entrance fees to the park.

question: When a good does not have a price attached to it, private markets
option: are characterized by market failure.
can sometimes be improved by the government.
cannot ensure that the good is produced and consumed in the proper amounts.
all of the above
answer: all of the above

question: Fire protection is a good example of a natural monopoly good because
option: it is rival.
it is nonexcludable.
it is always provided by the government.
protecting an extra house is unlikely to reduce the protection available to others.
answer: protecting an extra house is unlikely to reduce the protection available to others.

question: According to experience, the most effective solution to highway congestion is to
option: build more roads.
discourage urban sprawl by subsidizing urban apartment rents.
set a price for access to roads, which is paid by those who use them.
limit access to roads during the most congested times of the day.
answer: set a price for access to roads, which is paid by those who use them.

question: A common theme among examples of market failure is
option: the good being provided always harms society in some systematic way.
there are regulations that prohibit the efficient functioning of private markets.
some item of value does not have an owner with the legal authority to control it.
cost–benefit analysis is likely to lead to implementation policies that promote private provision of goods and services.
answer: some item of value does not have an owner with the legal authority to control it.

question: Two characteristics of any private good are
option: excludable and nonrival.
excludable and rival.
nonexcludable and rival.
nonexcludable and nonrival.
answer: excludable and rival.

question: What is meant by the non-excludability characteristic of public goods?
option: The government produces a good whether or not anyone wants to purchase the good.
The marginal cost of producing another unit of a good is zero.
Only the rich can afford a good so the poor are excluded.
The nature of a good allows individuals who do not pay for the good to consume it.
answer: The nature of a good allows individuals who do not pay for the good to consume it.

question: A good that is both nonrival and excludable would be a
option: common resource good.
natural monopoly.
public good.
private good.
answer: natural monopoly.

question: Which characteristic is associated with both public goods as well as common resources?
option: rival
nonrival
excludable
nonexcludable
answer: nonexcludable

question: Which of the following will NOT occur when a person uses a common resource?
option: It causes an externality.
Others will be worse off.
No one else will be able to use the common resource.
The person will probably not be charged for using the common resource.
answer: No one else will be able to use the common resource.

question: Which of the following would NOT be considered a private good?
option: clothing
pizza
Palm Pilot
cable TV
answer: cable TV

question: If the provision of public goods were left to the private sector
option: the outcome would be more efficient, because the government is notoriously inefficient.
more of the public goods would be produced than society desires.
the free-rider problem would cause less than the efficient quantity to be produced.
the government would be forced to raise taxes.
answer: the free-rider problem would cause less than the efficient quantity to be produced.

question: A free rider is a
option: person who will only purchase a product on sale.
person who receives the benefit of a good but avoids paying for it.
supplier who can produce a good at no cost.
person who takes advantage of tax loop-holes to lower his taxes.
answer: person who receives the benefit of a good but avoids paying for it.

question: Public goods such as national defense are provided by the government because
option: it is impossible for private markets to produce public goods.
products provided by the government can be produced more efficiently.
free riders make it difficult for private markets to supply the socially optimal quantity.
if the good were produced in private markets, most likely too much of the product would be produced.
answer: free riders make it difficult for private markets to supply the socially optimal quantity.

question: If the government decided to build a new highway, the first step would be to conduct a study to determine the value of the project. This study would be called a
option: fiscal analysis.
monetary analysis.
welfare analysis.
cost–benefit analysis.
answer: cost–benefit analysis.

question: It is apparent that externalities are present in a market whenever
option: a shortage exists.
the price is higher than equilibrium price.
private costs differ from social costs.
the seller is not making a profit.
answer: private costs differ from social costs.

question: Each of the following explain why cost–benefit analysis is such a difficult job EXCEPT
option: there is no price with which to judge the value of a public good.
surveys are often biased and unreliable.
it is difficult to identify all factors that influence the costs and benefits of public goods.
government projects rarely have sufficient funding to complete projects on time.
answer: government projects rarely have sufficient funding to complete projects on time.

question: To increase safety at a bad intersection, you must decide whether to install a traffic light in your hometown at a cost of $10,000. If the traffic light reduces the risk of fatality by 0.5 percent and the value of a human life is about $10 million, you should
option: install the light because the expected benefit of $50,000 is greater than the cost.
install the light because the expected benefit of $20,000 is greater than the cost.
not install the light because the expected benefit of $10,000 is only equal to the cost.
not install the light because the expected benefit of $5,000 is less than the cost.
answer: install the light because the expected benefit of $50,000 is greater than the cost.

question: When trying to determine if Americans would be willing to spend $1 billion to successfully restore salmon in the Snake River, the Army Corps of Engineers would be determining
option: moral value.
existence value.
restoration value.
public value.
answer: existence value.

question: Suppose twenty ranchers jointly own 5000 acres. Their cows graze on the land during spring and summer. The land becomes over-grazed. This is an example of
option: the Tragedy of the Commons.
an assignment of pollution rights.
negligence.
a positive externality.
answer: the Tragedy of the Commons.

question: The Tragedy of the Commons can be corrected by
option: providing more of the resource for public use.
assigning property rights to individuals.
providing government subsidies for the resource.
making certain everyone in the economy has access to the resource.
answer: assigning property rights to individuals.

question: If the use of a common resource is not regulated,
option: it cannot be used by anyone.
the economy will end up with too much of a good thing.
it becomes a private good.
it will be overused.
answer: it will be overused.

question: Knowledge is a good example of a
option: public good.
private good.
common resource.
natural monopoly good.
answer: public good.

question: In an attempt to remedy the presence of a negative externality such as pollution in a market, the government may choose to impose a
option: Pigovian tax.
subsidy.
command-and-control policy.
Coase theorem solution.
answer: Pigovian tax.

question: If a road is congested, then use of that road by an additional person would lead to a
option: negative externality.
positive externality.
natural monopoly problem.
free-rider problem with rush hour drivers stuck in traffic.
answer: negative externality.

question: The reason why elephants are endangered and cows are not is because
option: cows are not as valuable as elephants.
elephants are a common resource and cows are a private good.
cows are a common resource and elephants are a private good.
it is legal to kill cows, but not elephants.
answer: elephants are a common resource and cows are a private good.

question: It is common knowledge that many U.S. national parks have become overused. One possible solution to this problem is to
option: increase entrance fees.
conduct a study to determine the carrying capacity of the individual parks.
reduce the national park service budget.
All of the above are possible solutions.
answer: increase entrance fees.

question: National parks have become “overrun and overtrampled” primarily because
option: park administrators have not historically been the best managers of park resources.
national parks are treated as free goods by their visitors.
fees charged at national parks are used by the government to provide other public goods and not for park upkeep.
the entrance fee to national parks today is comparable to the fee charged at Disney World.
answer: national parks are treated as free goods by their visitors.

question: One problem that occurs when the government places a tax on gasoline is that it
option: does nothing to reduce traffic on the highways.
does not affect driving behavior at all.
does nothing to internalize the congestion externality problem.
discourages driving on congested roads, but also on noncongested roads that have no congestion externality.
answer: discourages driving on congested roads, but also on noncongested roads that have no congestion externality.

question: In all cases, the market fails to allocate resources efficiently because
option: the government refuses to intervene in private markets.
property rights are not well established.
individuals in private markets become too greedy.
only the government can allocate resources efficiently.
answer: property rights are not well established.

question: In designing a tax system, policymakers have two objectives:
option: equity and revenue.
revenue and debt reduction.
equity and efficiency.
revenue and expenditure.
answer: equity and efficiency.

question: The most common explanation for Social Security payments accounting for a larger share of federal government expenditures is
option: falling payroll tax receipts.
increases in life expectancy.
increases in birth rates among teenagers and the poor.
people becoming eligible for Social Security benefits at an earlier age.
answer: increases in life expectancy.

question: In general, the two most important taxes for state and local governments are
option: sales taxes and property taxes.
sin taxes and gasoline taxes.
income taxes and estate taxes.
excise taxes and corporate taxes.
answer: sales taxes and property taxes.

question: The biggest single expenditure for state and local governments is
option: Social Security.
education.
transportation.
unemployment compensation.
answer: education.

question: The largest source of revenue for the federal government is the
option: property tax.
corporate income tax.
individual income tax.
import and export tax.
answer: individual income tax.

question: As government debt increases,
option: a trade-off with government deficits is inevitable.
government must spend a larger share of its revenue on interest payments.
evidence suggests that spending on social insurance programs will be reduced.
all of the above
answer: government must spend a larger share of its revenue on interest payments.

question: A tax on the wages that a firm pays its workers is called a(n)
option: payroll tax.
excise tax.
income tax.
consumption tax.
answer: payroll tax.

question: When government receipts exceed total government spending during a fiscal year the difference
option: is a budget deficit.
is a budget surplus.
is the national debt.
becomes federal tax refunds.
answer: is a budget surplus.

question: When taxes are imposed on a commodity,
option: there is never a deadweight loss.
these taxes are considered nondistortionary.
tax revenue will rise by the amount of the tax multiplied by the before-tax level of consumption.
some consumers alter their consumption by not purchasing the taxed commodity.
answer: some consumers alter their consumption by not purchasing the taxed commodity.

question: The U.S. income tax
option: encourages saving.
has no effect on saving.
discourages saving.
will reduce the administrative burden of taxation.
answer: discourages saving.

question: When a taxpayer attempts to legally reduce her tax liability, she is engaging in
option: tax evasion.
tax avoidance.
a tax return compensation plan.
activities outside the intent of tax law.
answer: tax avoidance.

question: When tax laws give preferential treatment to specific types of behavior it is called
option: a political payoff.
tax evasion.
a tax loophole.
compensation for the benefit of society.
answer: a tax loophole.

question: As tax laws become more complex,
option: compliance costs are most likely to decrease.
the administrative burden of taxes is increased.
the government always collects more in tax revenue.
the amount of tax revenue lost to tax evasion always decreases.
answer: the administrative burden of taxes is increased.

question: If marginal tax rates increase, the
option: average tax rate will be falling.
deadweight loss from taxes will rise.
deadweight loss from taxes is unaffected.
deadweight loss from taxes will be reduced.
answer: deadweight loss from taxes will rise.

question: The extra taxes paid on an additional dollar of taxable income is called the
option: average tax liability.
average tax rate.
marginal tax liability.
marginal tax rate.
answer: marginal tax rate.

question: If the government were to impose a tax that assigned everyone the same tax liability, it would be

the output effect tends to raise profits while the price effect tends to decrease profits.
the output effect tends to decrease profits while the price effect tends to raise profits.
answer: the output effect tends to raise profits while the price effect tends to decrease profits.

question: As the number of sellers in an oligopoly rises, the magnitude of the price effect
option: rises, and the output effect vanishes.
rises, but the output effect remains.
falls, and the output effect vanishes.
falls, but the output effect remains.
answer: falls, but the output effect remains.

question: The prisoners’ dilemma helps to explain why cooperation
option: occurs in strategic situations.
is difficult to maintain in strategic situations.
is mutually beneficial in strategic situations.
never occurs in strategic situations.
answer: is difficult to maintain in strategic situations.

question: Game theory is especially relevant to understanding
option: competitive markets.
monopoly markets.
oligopoly markets.
None of the above is correct.
answer: oligopoly markets.

question: A tit-for-tat strategy
option: performed the best of many strategies compared in a tournament.
requires that if one party reneges, that the other will follow her dominant strategy forever.
implies that oligopolists will produce closer to the socially efficient level than if each firm sticks to its dominant strategy.
makes it difficult for oligopolists to cooperate.
answer: performed the best of many strategies compared in a tournament.

question: Suppose that a manufacturer requires that the retailers handling its product enter into resale price maintenance (RPM) agreements. This:
option: eliminates all competition among those retailers.
enables the manufacturer to charge a higher wholesale price to the retailers than would otherwise be possible.
may increase the amount of service that customers receive.
forces the retailers to accept a lower mark-up over the wholesale price than they would obtain without RPM.
answer: may increase the amount of service that customers receive.

question: Which of the following is incorrect?
option: To move the allocation of resources closer to the social optimum, policymakers should try to induce firms in an oligopoly to compete rather than cooperate.
For many centuries, judges in England and the United States have deemed agreements among competitors to reduce quantities and raise prices to be contrary to the public good.
It is unclear whether tying has adverse economic effects for society as a whole.
Predatory pricing may be considered a type of price discrimination.
answer: Predatory pricing may be considered a type of price discrimination.

question: The Sherman Act
option: made agreements to restrain trade among competitors unenforceable.
made agreements to restrain trade among competitors a criminal conspiracy.
allowed persons who could prove that they were damaged by illegal trade to sue the conspiring firms.
All of the above are correct.
answer: made agreements to restrain trade among competitors a criminal conspiracy.

question: To prevent discount retailers from free riding on information provided about goods by other retailers, wholesalers may use
option: resale price maintenance.
predatory pricing.
price discrimination.
tying.
answer: resale price maintenance.

question: Tying
option: has not yet been banned by the U.S. court system.
is probably used to prevent a free-rider problem.
is, according to most economists, likely used by firms to expand market power.
may be used as a form of price discrimination.
answer: may be used as a form of price discrimination.

question: In a monopolistically competitive industry, profit-maximizing firms are price
option: takers who produce a quantity where price is equal to marginal cost.
takers who produce a quantity where price is greater than marginal cost.
setters who set price equal to marginal cost.
setters who set price above marginal cost.
answer: setters who set price above marginal cost.

question: When free entry is one of the attributes of a market structure, economic profits in the long run
option: are equal to implicit cost.
are greater than implicit cost.
are zero.
depend on whether or not firms produce identical products.
answer: are zero.

question: The profit-maximizing rule for a firm in a monopolistically competitive market is to produce the quantity at which
option: average revenue equals average total cost.
average total cost is at its minimum.
marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
marginal cost is at its minimum.
answer: marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

question: Product differentiation causes the seller of a good to face what type of demand curve?
option: upward sloping
downward sloping
horizontal
vertical
answer: downward sloping

question: A monopolistically competitive firm chooses
option: the quantity of output to produce and the price of its output.
the quantity of output to produce, but the market determines price.
the price, but competition in the market determines the quantity.
only whether to enter or exit the market.
answer: the quantity of output to produce and the price of its output.

question: If firms in a monopolistically competitive market are earning negative economic profits, which of the following scenarios would best reflect the change facing incumbent firms as the market adjusts to its new equilibrium?
option: a downward shift in their marginal cost curve
an upward shift in their marginal cost curve
a decrease in demand
an increase in demand
answer: an increase in demand

question: As new firms enter a monopolistically competitive market, profits of existing firms
option: decline and product diversity in the market increases.
decline and product diversity in the market decreases.
rise and product diversity in the market decreases.
rise and product diversity in the market increases.
answer: decline and product diversity in the market increases.

question: When a profit-maximizing firm in a monopolistically competitive market is producing the long-run equilibrium quantity,
option: its demand curve will be tangent to its average total cost curve.
it will be earning economic profits.
its average revenue will equal marginal cost.
All of the above are correct.
answer: its demand curve will be tangent to its average total cost curve.

question: Since a firm in a monopolistically competitive market faces a
option: downward-sloping demand curve, it will always operate at efficient scale.
perfectly inelastic demand curve, it will always operate at efficient scale.
perfectly elastic demand curve, it will always operate at excess capacity.
downward-sloping demand curve, it will always operate at excess capacity.
answer: downward-sloping demand curve, it will always operate at excess capacity.

question: Monopolistically competitive firms operate at
option: excess capacity, so that additional production would raise average total cost.
excess capacity, so that additional production would lower average total cost.
efficient scale, so that additional production would raise average total cost.
efficient scale, so that additional production would lower average total cost.
answer: excess capacity, so that additional production would lower average total cost.

question: In the long run, a firm in a perfectly competitive market operates at
option: excess capacity and so do monopolistically competitive firms.
excess capacity while monopolistically competitive firm operate at efficient scale.
efficient scale and so do monopolistically competitive firms.
efficient scale while monopolistically competitive firms operate at excess capacity.
answer: efficient scale while monopolistically competitive firms operate at excess capacity.

question: A monopolistically competitive market could be considered inefficient because
option: price exceeds marginal cost.
marginal cost exceeds average revenue.
firms in monopolistically competitive markets often collude.
mark-up pricing does not occur in any other market structure.
answer: price exceeds marginal cost.

question: The deadweight loss that is associated with a monopolistically competitive market is a result of
option: operating in a constant cost industry.
pricing above marginal cost.
advertising costs.
pricing below marginal cost in order to increase market share.
answer: pricing above marginal cost.

question: The administrative burden of regulating price in a monopolistically competitive market is
option: small because firms produce at under-capacity.
small due to economies of scale.
large because of a large number of firms that produce differentiated products.
large because price is usually below marginal cost.
answer: large because of a large number of firms that produce differentiated products.

question: If regulators required firms in monopolistically competitive markets to set price equal to marginal cost,
option: firms would most likely experience economic losses.
firms would also operate at the efficient scale.
new firms would be likely to enter the market.
the most efficient firms are not likely to be affected.
answer: firms would most likely experience economic losses.

question: When the loss from a business-stealing externality exceeds the gain from a product-variety externality,
option: market efficiency is likely to be enhanced by the entry of new firms.
there are likely to be too many firms in a monopolistically competitive market.
the market structure is likely to be above the efficient scale.
firms are more likely to operate at efficient scale.
answer: there are likely to be too many firms in a monopolistically competitive market.

question: If advertising decreases the elasticity of demand for a firm’s product, the firm is likely to
option: lower their advertising budget.
become more competitive.
charge a larger mark-up over marginal cost.
produce above the efficient scale.
answer: charge a larger mark-up over marginal cost.

question: In recent years, the courts have been
option: less lenient of advertising in order to enhance the ability of markets to allocate resources efficiently.
less lenient of advertising in order to decrease elasticity of demand for specific products.
more lenient of advertising in order to enhance brand loyalty.
more lenient of advertising in order to enhance competition in markets.
answer: more lenient of advertising in order to enhance competition in markets.

question: When firms in a monopolistically competitive market engage in price-related advertising, defenders of advertising argue that
option: the quality of products sold in the market always increases.
customers are less likely to be informed about other characteristics of the product.
new firms are discouraged from entering the market.
each firm has less market power.
answer: each firm has less market power.

question: Results of the study done by Lee Benham on advertising for eyeglasses suggests that
option: optometrists would enthusiastically endorse advertising restrictions.
brand loyalty and market power in the eyeglass market was likely to be more pervasive in states that allowed advertising.
advertising restrictions were clearly beneficial to societal welfare.
eyeglass sales were more profitable in states that allowed advertising.
answer: optometrists would enthusiastically endorse advertising restrictions.

question: Defenders of advertising argue that it is not rational for profit-maximizing firms to spend money on advertising for products that have
option: low prices.
high prices.
superior quality.
inferior quality.
answer: inferior quality.

question: In some countries, brand name fast-food restaurants are not allowed to operate. Such restrictions are likely to
option: reduce barriers to entry in imperfect markets.
reduce the competitive nature of local fast-food markets.
enhance the social well-being of society.
enhance the choice set of consumers among local restaurants.
answer: reduce the competitive nature of local fast-food markets.

question: Viola uses only Log Cabin® brand maple syrup on her pancakes. She claims that even though generic maple syrups are cheaper, that they often seem watery. In a blind taste test Viola prefers a generic maple syrup. Her behavior is consistently explained by which of the following?
option: Consumers of brand-name products do not know their true preferences.
Consumers may choose brand-names to ensure the general quality of the product.
Consumers of brand-name products are likely to be uninformed about the quality of competing generic products.
None of the above is consistent.
answer: Consumers may choose brand-names to ensure the general quality of the product.

question: Monopolistic competition is characterized by
option: few sellers and free entry.
few sellers and restricted entry.
many sellers and free entry.
many sellers and restricted entry.
answer: many sellers and free entry.

question: Which of the following products is likely to be sold in a monopolistically competitive market?
option: crude oil
electricity
wheat
furniture
answer: furniture

question: The demand curve of a monopolistically competitive firm is
option: downward sloping; as it also is for a monopolist.
downward sloping; as it also is for monopolists and perfectly competitive firms.
horizontal; as it also is for a perfectly competitive firm.
horizontal; as it also is for monopolists and perfectly competitive firms.
answer: downward sloping; as it also is for a monopolist.

question: A monopolistically competitive firm maximizes profits by setting quantity and/or price according to the same rule as
option: a perfectly competitive firm.
a monopolist.
an oligopolist.
None of the above is correct.
answer: a monopolist.

question: A monopolistically competitive firm maximizes profits at the quantity where
option: average total cost = marginal cost.
average total cost = average revenue.
marginal revenue = average revenue.
marginal revenue = marginal cost.
answer: marginal revenue = marginal cost.

question: A monopolistically competitive firm maximizes its profits and has profits greater than zero if
option: average total cost equals average revenue and average total cost is greater than price.
average total cost equals average revenue and average total cost is less than price.
marginal revenue equals marginal cost and average total cost is greater than price.
marginal revenue equals marginal cost and average total cost is less than price.
answer: marginal revenue equals marginal cost and average total cost is less than price.

question: When price is above average total cost in a monopolistically competitive market
option: new firms enter the market, and the demand curves of existing firms shift left.
new firms enter the market and the demand curves of existing firms shifts right.
some firms exit the market and the demand curves of existing firms shifts left.
some firms exit the market and the demand curve of existing firms shifts right.
answer: new firms enter the market, and the demand curves of existing firms shift left.

question: When a monopolistically competitive firm is in long-run equilibrium
option: economic profits will be zero.
marginal cost exceeds price.
marginal revenue exceeds marginal cost.
All of the above are correct.
answer: economic profits will be zero.

question: Which of the following is correct?
option: Monopolistically competitive firms are price takers.
For monopolistically competitive firms the marginal revenue curve lies above the demand curve.
Under monopolistic competition, if price exceeds average total cost, firms will enter the market.
For monopolistically competitive firms, price equals marginal cost in the long run.
answer: Under monopolistic competition, if price exceeds average total cost, firms will enter the market.

question: Consider the following two sentences. Because the demand curve of a monopolistically competitive firm is downward sloping, its marginal revenue is less than price. Because there is free entry into monopolistically competitive markets, in the long-run economic profits are driven to zero.
option: Both sentences are correct.
Both sentences are incorrect.
Only the first sentence is correct.
Only the second sentence is correct.
answer: Both sentences are correct.

question: Consider the following two sentences. Both perfectly competitive and monopolistically competitive firms produce at the efficient scale. Perfectly competitive firms produce where price equals marginal cost, while monopolistically competitive firms produce where price is greater than marginal cost.
option: Both sentences are correct.
Neither sentence is correct.
Only the first sentence is correct.
Only the second sentence is correct.
answer: Only the second sentence is correct.

question: A monopolistically competitive firm in the long run produces
option: a quantity less than the efficient scale.
at the efficient scale.
at a quantity above the efficient scale.
None of the above is necessarily correct, it depends on whether firms are making economic profits greater than zero.
answer: a quantity less than the efficient scale.

question: In the long run profit-maximizing monopolistically competitive firms charge a price
option: above average total cost, but less than marginal cost.
above average total cost, but greater than marginal cost.
equal to average total cost, but less than marginal cost.
equal to average total cost, but greater than marginal cost.
answer: equal to average total cost, but greater than marginal cost.

question: Excess capacity arises under conditions of monopolistic competition because:
option: there is underutilization of resources and not enough firms.
the output produced does not minimize average total cost.
a monopolistically competitive firm produces more output than would be produced by a perfectly competitive firm.
there are too many goods chasing too few resources.
answer: the output produced does not minimize average total cost.

question: Which of the externalities created by the entry of a new firm exists under both perfect competition and monopolistic competition?
option: only the product-variety externality
only the business-stealing externality
both the product-variety externality and the business-stealing externality
neither the product-variety externality nor the business-stealing externality
answer: neither the product-variety externality nor the business-stealing externality

question: Requiring monopolistic competitors to set price equal to marginal cost would
option: be a burden because there are so many producers of differentiated products.
cause them to make losses.
Both of the above are correct.
None of the above is correct.
answer: Both of the above are correct.

question: The number of firms in a monopolistically competitive market is likely to be too small
option: if the product-variety externality is larger than the business-stealing externality.
if the business-stealing externality is larger than the product-variety externality.
if there are either business-stealing externalities or product-variety externalities.
under no conditions, monopolistically competitive markets always have a larger number of firms than is socially efficient.
answer: if the product-variety externality is larger than the business-stealing externality.

question: Monopolistic competition results in inefficiency because
option: they can earn an economic profit in the short run.
price is not equal to average total cost in the long run.
firms exit the industry in response to losses.
price is greater than marginal cost.
answer: price is greater than marginal cost.

question: In which of the following markets are advertising expenditures as a percent of revenues likely to be highest?
option: perfect competition.
monopoly.
monopolistic competition.
None of the above is necessarily likely to spend a larger share of revenues on advertising than the others.
answer: monopolistic competition.

question: Critics of advertising argue that advertising:
option: increases the elasticity of demand for the firm’s product.
impedes competition.
decreases demand for the firm’s product.
decreases supply of the firm’s product.
answer: impedes competition.

question: Suppose that by advertising, fast food places are able to increase the perception that their products are unique and so foster brand loyalty. The demand curves for the products of these firms become
option: more elastic, so markup increases.
more elastic, so markup decreases.
less elastic, so markup increases.
less elastic, so markup decreases.
answer: less elastic, so markup increases.

question: Which of the following is incorrect?
option: Courts have recently concluded that restrictions on advertising by certain professions served mostly to curtail competition.
A study showed that the average price of eyeglasses was higher in states that allowed advertising than in states that did not.
By their willingness to spend money on advertising alone, firms signal that their products are not of inferior quality.
Advertising may lead to a more efficient allocation of resources.
answer: A study showed that the average price of eyeglasses was higher in states that allowed advertising than in states that did not.

question: Brand loyalty may
option: provide incentive for brand names to offer products of consistently high quality.
make demand for the brand’s product more elastic.
tend to push average total cost towards price.
All of the above are correct.
answer: provide incentive for brand names to offer products of consistently high quality.

question: Factors of production are best defined as the
option: wages paid to the workforce.
goods and services sold in the market.
output produced from raw materials.
inputs used to produce goods and services.
answer: inputs used to produce goods and services.

question: Since a firm’s demand for a factor of production comes from its decision to supply a good in the market, we refer to this type of demand as
option: supplied demand.
derived demand.
secondary demand.
differentiated demand.
answer: derived demand.

question: Most of the total income earned in the U.S. economy is ultimately paid to households in the form of
option: rent.
wages.
interest.
profit.
answer: wages.

question: The production function describes the relationship between
option: inputs and cost.
outputs and profit.
inputs and outputs.
inputs and revenue.
answer: inputs and outputs.

question: The marginal product of labor is defined as the increase in
option: revenue per additional unit of input.
output per additional unit of input.
revenue per additional unit of output.
output per additional unit of revenue.
answer: output per additional unit of input.

question: If hiring more workers causes each additional worker to contribute less to the total output,
option: diminishing profitability is present.
increasing marginal product is present.
diminishing marginal product is present.
diminishing marginal cost is present.
answer: diminishing marginal product is present.

question: The value of the marginal product of labor is equal to the change in
option: marginal cost with the addition of the last worker.
total cost with the addition of the last worker.
total profit with the addition of the last worker.
total revenue with the addition of the last worker.
answer: total revenue with the addition of the last worker.

question: A competitive, profit-maximizing firm hires workers until
option: the value of the marginal product equals the wage.
unemployment rates are zero.
marginal product equals zero.
marginal revenue equals zero.
answer: the value of the marginal product equals the wage.

question: A worker’s contribution to a firm’s revenue is measured directly by the worker’s
option: contribution to output.
value of marginal product.
marginal product minus his/her wage.
marginal product multiplied by his/her wage.
answer: value of marginal product.

question: A profit-maximizing competitive firm that experiences diminishing marginal product of labor is also experiencing
option: an upward-sloping demand for labor.
a downward-sloping demand for labor.
a perfectly elastic supply of labor.
a perfectly inelastic supply of labor.
answer: a downward-sloping demand for labor.

question: If one observes a profit-maximizing firm increasing employment, it is possible to infer that the
option: firm is increasing its market share.
marginal product is rising.
wage exceeds the value of the marginal product.
value of the marginal product exceeds the wage.
answer: value of the marginal product exceeds the wage.

question: If the price of airline tickets rises, what will happen to the demand curve for flight attendants?
option: It will shift to the left.
It will shift to the right.
There will be a movement along the curve.
It will remain unchanged; price changes do not shift demand curves.
answer: It will shift to the right.

question: Which of the following events would cause an increase in the labor supply curve?
option: more married women deciding to work
a lower Social Security retirement age
fewer married men deciding to work
tighter restrictions on immigration policy
answer: more married women deciding to work

question: When labor supply increases,
option: profit-maximizing firms reduce employment.
the marginal productivity of workers always increases.
wages increase as long as supply is upward sloping.
wages decrease as long as labor demand is downward sloping.
answer: wages decrease as long as labor demand is downward sloping.

question: Which of the following could decrease labor demand?
option: an increase in migrant workers
a decrease in the labor supply
a decrease in demand for the final product produced by labor
an increase in the marginal productivity of workers
answer: a decrease in demand for the final product produced by labor

question: When firms are able to increase the amount of physical capital available to workers the
option: value of the marginal product of labor will decrease.
value of the marginal product of labor will increase.
final product price will increase.
marginal product of labor will decline.
answer: value of the marginal product of labor will increase.

question: When economists refer to a firm’s capital, they are likely to be using the term to describe the
option: markets for final goods and services.
amount of financing provided by the equity markets.
stock of equipment and buildings used in production.
amount of bank financing used by the firm.
answer: stock of equipment and buildings used in production.

question: The purchase price of land is
option: the price received from the flow of some land services.
the price a person pays to own the factor of production.
always less than the rental price.
the value of the land to the firm this time period.
answer: the price a person pays to own the factor of production.

question: The marginal product of any factor of production depends on
option: the price of the final good.
the quantity of the factor used.
the demand for the final good.
whether it is used to produce a good or a service.
answer: the quantity of the factor used.

question: As a result of severe flooding, a farmer loses one-half of his productive farmland. He should expect to see the marginal productivity of his land
option: increase.
decrease.
become negative.
remain unchanged.
answer: increase.

question: The change in the supply of one factor
option: alters the earnings of all factors.
will not alter the marginal productivity of other factors, but may lower their price.
will not lower the price of other factors, but may alter their marginal productivity.
will not change the value of marginal product for other factors.
answer: alters the earnings of all factors.

question: For the profit-maximizing competitive firm, the value of marginal product curve is
option: always rising.
the labor supply curve.
the labor demand curve.
falling only when marginal product is rising.
answer: the labor demand curve.

question: Which of the following would be considered capital?
option: Tiger Woods’ golf clubs
Greg Mankiw’s Ph.D.
a West Virginia coal mine
the Kansas City Chiefs’ defensive coach
answer: Tiger Woods’ golf clubs

question: The most important factor of product based on income earned in the U.S. economy is
option: land.
labor.
capital.
profit.
answer: labor.

question: Derived demand refers to the fact that the demand for a factor of production is derived from the
option: supply of that factor of production.
level of a firm’s investment.
demand for the product it produces.
equilibrium price for that factor of production in the market.
answer: demand for the product it produces.

question: A production function shows the relationship between the quantity of
option: inputs used to make a good and the cost associated with those inputs.
inputs used to make a good and the quantity of output of that good.
output of a good and the amount of profit a firm makes from the sale of that good.
inputs used to make a good and the total revenue generated by the sale of that good.
answer: inputs used to make a good and the quantity of output of that good.

question: The value of the marginal product curve is downward sloping because
option: as firms hire additional workers, profit for the firm declines.
of the law of diminishing marginal product.
as firms hire additional workers, they are forced to hire less-qualified workers.
firms must lower the price of their product in order to sell more of it.
answer: of the law of diminishing marginal product.

question: The increase in the amount of output from an additional unit of labor is called
option: derived demand.
diminishing marginal product.
factors of production.
the marginal product of labor.
answer: the marginal product of labor.

question: For a profit-maximizing firm, the decision to employ an additional worker is based on how
option: long the worker plans to stay with the company.
profitable that worker will be to the firm.
much of the product the worker can produce.
much experience the worker has with that type of job.
answer: profitable that worker will be to the firm.

question: The value of the marginal product of labor is equal to
option: total output divided by the quantity of labor.
the price of the output the labor produced.
the marginal product of labor times the price of the output.
the supply curve for labor.
answer: the marginal product of labor times the price of the output.

question: The competitive, profit-maximizing firm’s demand for labor curve is
option: a horizontal line in perfectly competitive industries.
typically more elastic than the demand for the product the firms are producing.
equal to the supply of labor when markets are in equilibrium.
equal to the value of the marginal product of labor curve.
answer: equal to the value of the marginal product of labor curve.

question: If the price of televisions falls, the value of the marginal product of workers making televisions will
option: definitely fall.
definitely rise.
not change.
fall or rise; we do not have enough information to know for certain.
answer: definitely fall.

question: If Kansans begin moving to Colorado to live because of the beautiful scenery, we would expect
option: firms to automatically relocate to Kansas.
the supply of labor to increase in Kansas and decrease in Colorado.
the supply of labor to increase in Colorado and decrease in Kansas.
wages to increase in Colorado and decrease in Kansas.
answer: the supply of labor to increase in Colorado and decrease in Kansas.

question: Plainco Corporations sells widgets for $3 each in a market that is perfectly competitive. Increasing the number of Plainco workers from 1,000 to 1,001 would cause output to rise from 615 to 625 widgets per day. Plainco should hire the 1,001st worker only when
option: the wage is $30 or less per day.
the wage is more than $30 per day.
the wage is $6.25 or less per day.
workers are willing to work on a piecework basis.
answer: the wage is $30 or less per day.

question: Which of the following would NOT increase the demand for labor?
option: an increase in the final product price
an increase in the amount of capital available for workers to use
an increase in the marginal productivity of workers
an increase in the wage labor receives
answer: an increase in the wage labor receives

question: Each of the following is a key determinant of labor productivity EXCEPT the amount of
option: human capital acquired through education and training.
technological knowledge that is available.
tools and equipment that is available.
annual growth the company experiences.
answer: annual growth the company experiences.

question: The value of the marginal product curve is also a firm’s
option: total revenue curve.
supply curve for labor.
demand curve for labor.
production function.
answer: demand curve for labor.

question: If the price of Godiva chocolates increases, we would expect that this company’s wages will
option: rise and fewer workers will be hired.
fall and more workers will be hired.
rise and more workers will be hired.
fall and fewer workers will be hired.
answer: rise and more workers will be hired.

question: Workers who acquire additional training or education should expect
option: a wage increase, since they now should be more productive.
to be fired, since they are now overqualified for their job.
to be required to train other workers for the firm.
to have less need for physical capital associated with their job.
answer: a wage increase, since they now should be more productive.

question: An orange grower in Florida who loses most of his orange trees to a hard freeze should expect the marginal productivity of his capital to
option: increase.
decrease.
stay the same.
be negative.
answer: decrease.

question: An upward-sloping supply curve means that
option: workers prefer to work less when wages are high.
workers prefer to buy more leisure time when their incomes increase.
an increase in wages causes workers to increase the quantity of labor they supply.
workers will attempt to buy more leisure time and supply more labor when wages rise.
answer: an increase in wages causes workers to increase the quantity of labor they supply.

question: Given a downward-sloping demand for labor curve, if the supply of labor increases, we would expect
option: firms will choose to hire fewer workers.
a shortage of workers in most industries.
the equilibrium wage to fall.
the value of the marginal product of labor to rise.
answer: the equilibrium wage to fall.

question: The price paid to any factor of production
option: decreases when the demand for that factor increases.
is equal to the value of the marginal product of that factor.
increases as more of the factor is used in the production process.
will be greater than the value of the marginal product of that factor if the firm is a profit-maximizer.
answer: is equal to the value of the marginal product of that factor.

question: When wage differentials are observed in competitive labor markets, the neoclassical theory of labor markets would predict
option: market discrimination.
that wage differences reflect social status.
that wages will converge over time.
a difference in the value of marginal product of labor.
answer: a difference in the value of marginal product of labor.

question: The job of night watchman at the Punxsutawny Phil Groundhog museum is known to have a high wage. This is likely to be partially explained by the fact that the job
option: is likely to be incredibly dull.
is likely to be difficult.
is likely to require specialized skills.
provides plenty of time for self-reflection.
answer: is likely to be incredibly dull.

question: The term “compensating differential” refers to
option: the fact that workers that do similar work should be paid the same wage.
a wage difference that arises from nonmonetary characteristics of different jobs.
a wage difference that is distinguishable on the basis of monetary characteristics.
all of the above.
answer: a wage difference that arises from nonmonetary characteristics of different jobs.

question: A recent law school graduate is considering two offers to practice law, one in California and one in Mississippi. Rumor has it that it is very difficult to pass the Mississippi bar exam and meet other certification requirements required by the Mississippi Attorney Association. Assuming all other things are equal, the attorney would expect
option: wages in California and Mississippi to be identical.
to make a lower wage in Mississippi.
to make a higher wage in Mississippi.
to be unable to predict the wage difference between Mississippi and California.
answer: to make a higher wage in Mississippi.

question: Public schoolteachers are known to have low wages. This is likely to be partially explained by the fact that
option: public schoolteacher jobs are easy.
public schoolteachers need very little money to live.
public schoolteachers are required to be college graduates.
many people perceive the job of public schoolteacher to have a high element of personal satisfaction.
answer: many people perceive the job of public schoolteacher to have a high element of personal satisfaction.

question: Workers that have invested in human capital are
option: universally less productive in “dull” jobs.
likely to have a higher value of marginal product.
likely to have a lower value of marginal product.
not likely to have changed the value of their marginal product.
answer: likely to have a higher value of marginal product.

question: By 1998, the earnings gap between both men and women college graduates in the United States and those with only a high school diploma increased to
option: 118 percent for men and 98 percent for women.
66 percent for men and 55 percent for women.
85 percent for men and 40 percent for women.
98 percent for men and 118 percent for women.
answer: 118 percent for men and 98 percent for women.

question: The statement “the rich get richer and the poor get poorer” is evident in the fact that
option: developing countries do not pay workers the value of their marginal product.
developed economies export high-skill jobs to developing countries.
the poor must shoulder an increasing amount of the public debt.
the earnings gap between high-skill jobs and low-skill jobs has increased over the last several years.
answer: the earnings gap between high-skill jobs and low-skill jobs has increased over the last several years.

question: Economists who study labor markets have discovered that
option: ability, effort, and chance are likely to be significant contributors to wage differences.
only about 5 percent of wage differences are related to chance.
ability is not difficult to measure, but is largely insignificant in explaining wage differences.
work effort is difficult to measure, but is not likely to contribute much to an explanation of wage differences.
answer: ability, effort, and chance are likely to be significant contributors to wage differences.

question: Empirical analysis of wage differences has found evidence
option: of a minor role played by omitted variables.
of a direct correlation between wages and attractiveness.
that the physical appearance of people in identical jobs is not likely to impact their wages.
that suggests that physical appearance-related wage differentials among males are vastly different than differentials among females.
answer: of a direct correlation between wages and attractiveness.

question: According to the human capital view, education
option: alters work ethic.
leads to lower lifetime earnings.
enhances productivity.
is an indicator of raw intellect.
answer: enhances productivity.

question: The fact that women are more likely to interrupt their careers to raise children reflects
option: further evidence that labor markets discriminate against women.
evidence that society under-values the role of women in the market place.
a potential market-based reason why average wages for men exceed those for women.
evidence that markets are inefficient at allocating labor resources.
answer: a potential market-based reason why average wages for men exceed those for women.

question: Evidence suggests that business owners are generally
option: interested in profits, only when discrimination is illegal.
more interested in discrimination than in making a profit.
unable to determine the link between discrimination and profitability.
more interested in making a profit than in discriminating against a particular group.
answer: more interested in making a profit than in discriminating against a particular group.

question: Discriminatory hiring practices can be expected, even if markets are competitive, as a result of
option: lower costs of hiring.
customer preferences.
a perfectly elastic market demand.
unrestricted entry and exit in markets.
answer: customer preferences.

question: The issue of comparable worth is one in which
option: all workers should receive the same wages in an economy.
markets are allowed to determine a worker’s rate of compensation.
workers with “comparable” education, experience, responsibility, and working conditions would be compensated at similar wage rates.
all workers should be provided an opportunity to make a comparable contribution to the economy.
answer: workers with “comparable” education, experience, responsibility, and working conditions would be compensated at similar wage rates.

question: Which of the following scenarios would serve to decrease the demand for unskilled labor in our country?
option: increased international trade with countries where unskilled labor is more plentiful
increased demand for goods produced by unskilled labor
increased productivity gains among the unskilled laborers
increased supply of migrant workers
answer: increased international trade with countries where unskilled labor is more plentiful

question: Why do major league baseball players get paid more than minor league players?
option: The higher wage reflects a compensating differential.
Major league players are better athletes.
The higher wage is often due to educational discrepancies.
Playing in the major leagues is less pleasant than playing in the minor leagues.
answer: Major league players are better athletes.

question: Which of the following statements represents the idea behind signaling in education?
option: Education can turn an unproductive person into a productive person.
The more naturally productive someone is the more they are inclined to educate themselves.
Most college graduates wouldn’t be half as productive if it were not for the years they spend in the classroom.
all of the above
answer: The more naturally productive someone is the more they are inclined to educate themselves.

question: Studies have shown that nonunion workers earn about
option: 10 to 20 percent less than union workers.
10 to 20 percent more than union workers.
40 to 50 percent more than union workers.
40 to 50 percent less than union workers.
answer: 10 to 20 percent less than union workers.

question: How does the theory of efficiency wages explain above-equilibrium wages?
option: Employers are forced to pay higher wages in efficient markets.
Workers get a raise in wage when they prove they are increasing their productivity.
Workers demand higher wages to compensate for poor fringe benefits.
Employers give their workers a higher wage in the hopes that it will lead to increased productivity.
answer: Employers give their workers a higher wage in the hopes that it will lead to increased productivity.

question: Racial segregation of streetcars in the southern cities was largely opposed by
option: streetcar firms.
government officials.
Sherman antitrust laws.
all of the above.
answer: streetcar firms.

question: What was the main reason the gender gap did not narrow during the post-war years?
option: Women added more to marginal product than men.
Employers were required to pay men more to do the same job women were doing.
Many of the women who entered the labor force had not worked for quite some time and therefore lacked experience.
all of the above
answer: Many of the women who entered the labor force had not worked for quite some time and therefore lacked experience.

question: Economists would argue that the gender wage gap is narrowing because of
option: efficiency wages.
comparable worth legislation.
decreased productivity among male workers.
